questions.prompt: Does peanut butter ADHERE to bread?
Would you like a person to show CONTEMPT for you?
Is a CORDIAL person likely to be friendly to you?
Would most people like to pay EXORBITANT prices for food?
Is it usually easy to find someone else's HOARD?
Is a JEST supposed to make people laugh?
Does MAULING a person cause him injury?
Would an evil person usually have great RENOWN?
Would most people like to buy a television that had been built in a SLIPSHOD manner?
Would fifty dollars SUFFICE to buy a new car?
Do you have a SURPLUS of money when you're broke?
Can you CONTEMPLATE when you are by yourself?
Is George Washington CONTEMPORARY with us?
He always ADHERED to the principle that honesty is the best policy.
I'm CONTEMPTUOUS of him because of the terrible things he does.
His CORDIALITY offended all of us; he never spoke to us the entire time we were at his house.
Ann was DISGRUNTLED when she learned that she would not be allowed to enter the contest.
No one believed his claims until he showed how EXORBITANT they were.
The old man was very generous; he always HOARDED money.
He only made that remark in JEST; please don't be upset by it.
The boxer was MAULED by his larger and more experienced opponent.
This artist is RENOWNED for her skillful use of bright colors.
I have never seen anyone looking so SLIPSHOD; her hair was freshly combed and her clothes were nicely cleaned and pressed.
He was a light eater. He thought that two carrots SUFFICED for dinner.
Last year there was a SURPLUS of gasoline, but this year there is hardly any.
A meter is a UNITY of length.
She is CONTEMPLATIVE of anyone who isn't as pretty as she is.
The author was widely admired by his CONTEMPORARIES, but after his death his reputation went down.

ADHERE.deftext:
to stick, hold fast 
To ADHERE to something is to stick to it. Physical objects can ADHERE to other objects, and people can ADHERE to goals, beliefs, causes, and the like. 
"The glue made the paper ADHERE to the table." 
"She ADHERED to her position even after she had been proved wrong." 
"I try to ADHERE to the Golden Rule in my everyday life." 
The most common mistake on the Pretest is to choose _loosen_ as the meaning of ADHERE. This is a confusion of a word with its opposite. 
Other forms of the word: ADHERENCE, n. ADHERENT, n. 
Usage: ADHERE is usually followed by _to_.

CONTEMPTUOUS.deftext:
showing CONTEMPT, scornful  
CONTEMPT is an attitude in which you despise or look down on someone or something. 
"He felt nothing but CONTEMPT for students who cheated on tests." 
 CONTEMPTUOUS is an adjective from CONTEMPT; it means "showing or feeling CONTEMPT." See _-ous_ under Suffixes. 
"She was CONTEMPTUOUS of people who used any means to get their own way." 
"The baseball coach was CONTEMPTUOUS of my attempt to throw a curveball." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer on the Pretest is _disgusting_. This may be due to confusion between CONTEMPTUOUS and CONTEMPTIBLE. CONTEMPTIBLE means "worthy of scorn or CONTEMPT." 
"Beating the dog severely was a CONTEMPTIBLE action. We are all CONTEMPTUOUS of such disgraceful behavior." 
Other forms of the word: CONTEMPT, n. CONTEMPTIBLE, adj.

CORDIAL.deftext:
warm, heartfelt, sincere 
CORDIAL comes from the Latin word for _heart_. CORDIAL means "coming from the heart"; the word is used about warm, sincere people and what they do or say. See _-al_ under Suffixes. 
"Our host gave us a CORDIAL greeting when we arrived for the party." 
"She was not very CORDIAL to us when we told her we didn't have enough money to pay the bill." 
"You are CORDIALLY invited to a fashion show next Saturday evening." 
CORDIALITY is warm affection or kindness. 
"Her CORDIALITY to the stranger made him feel like one of the family." 
Other forms of the word: CORDIALITY, n.

DISGRUNTLE.deftext:
to dissatisfy, make discontented  
DISGRUNTLE is related to the word _grunt_. Someone who is DISGRUNTLED has been put into a bad humor, has been made dissatisfied and discontented. 
"The workers were DISGRUNTLED at having to come in on their day off." 
"The DISGRUNTLED students complained to the teacher about the unfair test." 
"Jim was DISGRUNTLED to find out that someone else was going to play instead of him." 
Other forms of the word: DISGRUNTLEMENT, n. 
Usage: DISGRUNTLE is usually used in the form DISGRUNTLED.

EXORBITANT.deftext:
unreasonable, excessive, extravagant 
See _ex-_ under Prefixes and _-ant_ under Suffixes. An _orbit_ is a track or path, especially the path through space taken by an artificial satellite, the moon, or a planet. Something which is EXORBITANT is off the track, outside the usual course things take. The word is used about prices, claims, demands, and similar things to show that they are far beyond their usual limits. 
"I wanted to buy the hat, but I thought the price was EXORBITANT." 
"Her demands were so EXORBITANT that we wouldn't even consider them." 
"His claims for the new drug were EXORBITANT: he said it would cure any disease." 
Other forms of the word: EXORBITANCE, n.

HOARD.deftext:
a hidden supply, secret accumulation 
A HOARD is a hidden supply of something valuable saved up for future use. 
"The squirrel kept a HOARD of nuts in the hollow trunk of the tree." 
"They found a HOARD of gold coins which someone had hidden away in the cellar." 
To HOARD something is to save it up, to gather it into a HOARD, sometimes in a greedy way. 
"Expecting a food shortage, people started to HOARD flour and sugar." 
"The pirates HOARDED their treasure."

JEST.deftext:
a joke, funny remark 
JEST is a rather formal word for _joke._ 
"Only a few of his JESTS were funny." 
To say something "in JEST" is to say it in fun, without being serious. 
A JESTER is someone who makes JESTS; it was especially used about a professional fool or clown who worked for a king or nobleman. 
"He was the court JESTER. He had to make everyone laugh even when he was sad." 
Other forms of the word: JESTER, n.

MAUL.deftext:
to handle roughly and injuriously, beat, bruise 
A MAUL is a heavy hammer. MAUL also used to be the name of a heavy club used as a weapon. To MAUL someone is to treat or handle him roughly, as if you were hitting him with a heavy club. 
"The vicious mob MAULED the foreigners." 
"He went too close to the cage and was MAULED by the tiger."

RENOWN.deftext:
fame, celebrity, distinction, honor 
RENOWN is widespread fame and honor. RENOWN is a very positive word; it suggests that the fame is due to great accomplishments or virtues. 
"She is a writer of great RENOWN. She has won all kinds of awards." 
"The city enjoys considerable RENOWN for its many fine museums and parks." 
"Despite the actor's RENOWN the play was not very popular." 
RENOWNED means "having RENOWN," _famous_. 
"The RENOWNED general is paying us a visit." 
"Her pies are RENOWNED for their great flavor." 
Other forms of the word: RENOWNED, adj.

SLIPSHOD.deftext:
careless, sloppy 
SLIPSHOD used to mean "wearing slippers or shoes that are run down at the heels." From this idea of wearing old slippers SLIPSHOD has come to mean generally _careless_ or _sloppy_. 
"I will not pay for such SLIPSHOD work; you'll have to do it over again." 
"She is SLIPSHOD in her use of words." 
"He made a SLIPSHOD attempt to straighten up his room." 
Many people think SLIPSHOD means _incomplete_. The two words are close, since a SLIPSHOD job might involve leaving the work _incomplete_. The emphasis in SLIPSHOD, however, is on the sloppiness and lack of care.

SUFFICE.deftext:
to be enough, be sufficient, be adequate SUFFICE is a verb related to the word SUFFICIENT. To SUFFICE is to be SUFFICIENT, to be enough for a particular need or purpose. 
"A few pages SUFFICED to show us that the book wasn't very good." 
"He said that he would like twenty dollars, but that ten would SUFFICE." 
"Words cannot SUFFICE to make you understand how important this is." 
Other forms of the word: SUFFICIENT, adj.

SURPLUS.deftext:
excess, extra, left over 
That which is SURPLUS is left over after use or need has been satisfied. It is more than what is necessary. 
"Fewer people came than we expected, so we were left with SURPLUS food." 
"The farmers were able to sell their SURPLUS wheat." 
"Manufacturers could not get rid of their SURPLUS stock even at reduced prices." 
SURPLUS is also a noun; it is the amount that is greater than what is needed. 
"One year there is a shortage of sugar, and the next year there's a SURPLUS." 
"If you produce more than is required, you'll be stuck with the SURPLUS."

UNITY.deftext:
oneness; agreement 
UNITY is related to the words _unify_ and _unite._ All come from the Latin word meaning one. The basic meaning of UNITY is _oneness._ The word is applied to a whole which is made up of many different parts working together. 
"The removal of any one part would spoil the UNITY of the design." 
"The various states sought UNITY with one another in their struggle against England." 
Often UNITY stresses the cooperation and agreement that this oneness brings. 
"Despite their different backgrounds they lived and worked in UNITY."

CONTEMPLATIVE.deftext:
thoughtful, meditative, reflective 
To CONTEMPLATE something is to think deeply about it or to look at it thoughtfully. 
"She CONTEMPLATED the statue for hours." 
"He CONTEMPLATED the best way to escape from prison." 
CONTEMPLATIVE is the adjective from CONTEMPLATE. See _-ive_ under Suffixes. A CONTEMPLATIVE person is inclined to think deeply about things. 
"Whenever she was in a CONTEMPLATIVE mood she would sit and gaze out at the ocean for hours at a time." 
"His brother is energetic and quick to act, but Bill is very CONTEMPLATIVE. He likes to reflect upon things." 
Other forms of the word: CONTEMPLATE, v. CONTEMPLATION, n.

CONTEMPORARY.deftext:
occurring at the same time, simultaneous; modern, current 
Something which is CONTEMPORARY lives, exists, or occurs at the same time as something else. 
"Shakespeare's life was CONTEMPORARY with Francis Bacon's." 
"The revival of learning in the Renaissance was CONTEMPORARY with the early explorations of America." 
"CONTEMPORARY authors all described the ancient king as being short and ugly." 
CONTEMPORARY also means _modern_, _up-to-date-_ that is, existing at the same time we do. 
"Jane decided to sell all her antique furniture and redecorate her home in a more CONTEMPORARY style." 
CONTEMPORARY is also a noun which is used about people who live at the same time. 
"Roberta and my sister, Lorraine, were CONTEMPORARIES at Columbia University."

questions.prompt: Could the desire to make money OBSESS a person?
Would an EXULTANT person be angry?
Can you MEDITATE upon something you don't understand?
Can you DISINTEGRATE glass with a hammer?
Can a CHRONIC problem usually be solved easily?
Can pepper INDUCE sneezing in people?
Would a PUNY person be able to lift heavy weights?
Can people live in a PRECINCT?
Could the phrase "cold as ice" be considered a CLICHE?
Do PROLOGUES come at the end?
Do most people have hundreds of INTIMATE friends?
He ordered them to OBSESS their poor behavior.
The good news was so unexpected that they couldn't hide their EXULTATION.
For a long time she has MEDITATED quitting her job.
They said they were DISINTEGRATED and wouldn't be able to go to the movies.
Jim gave a quick SUMMIT of his reasons for leaving.
He is not very PROFICIENT in math, so I doubt that he'll want to become an engineer.
Bill is a CHRONIC liar. He only lies when he absolutely has to.
They INDUCED the number of students by transferring some to another school.
What a PUNY chicken; there's very little meat on its bones.
More than half of the crimes in the city are committed in that one PRECINCT.
His speech was so full of CLICHES that I don't think he wrote one original line himself.
The SULLEN sky seemed to add to our unhappiness.
As a PROLOGUE to the fashion show there was a brief speech about the history of clothes.
We must speed things up. The project has become very RELATED recently.
He developed an INTIMATE understanding of how governments work.

OBSESS.deftext:
to trouble continuously, haunt, beset 
OBSESS was originally used about an army besieging a town or a fortress, or an evil spirit haunting or possessing a person. From these uses the word has developed its current sense, "to trouble or distress continuously, to influence unreasonably." Now OBSESS is only used about ideas, fears, emotions, and other mental actions. 
"She was OBSESSED by the idea that someone was out to kill her." 
"These suspicions OBSESSED him so much that he couldn't sleep at night." 
"We were OBSESSED with the desire to become state champions." 
Other forms of the word: OBSESSION, n. OBSESSIVE, adj.

EXULT.deftext:
to rejoice, be very glad, be elated 
EXULT comes from a Latin word meaning to _leap up._ Someone who EXULTS is so happy that he could jump for joy. EXULT means about the same as _rejoice,_ but EXULT is even stronger, suggesting happiness and triumph that can scarcely be contained. 
"We EXULTED over winning the championship." 
"They EXULTED in their good luck." 
EXULTATION is the noun from EXULT, meaning _great joy, jubilation._ 
"We were full of EXULTATION when we passed the course." 
EXULTANT is the adjective from EXULT. 
"The crowd was EXULTANT over the news." 
Other forms of the word: EXULTANT, adj. EXULTATION, n.

MEDITATE.deftext:
to reflect, think, contemplate, ponder 
To MEDITATE is to think deeply and seriously. 
"He used to take long walks and MEDITATE upon the meaning of life." 
"She wanted to take some time to MEDITATE on these problems before making a decision." 
To MEDITATE something is to consider it or plan it in your mind. 
"He MEDITATED revenge for all the wrongs that had been done to him." 
Other forms of the word: MEDITATION, n. MEDITATIVE, adj. 
Usage: MEDITATE is often followed by _on or upon._

DISINTEGRATE.deftext:
to break up, fall apart 
When something DISINTEGRATES, it breaks up into small pieces. See _dis-_ under Prefixes. 
"The building DISINTEGRATED from the force of the explosion." 
"The rocks slowly DISINTEGRATED after centuries of storms and heat." 
To DISINTEGRATE something is to break it apart. 
"One blow of his ax DISINTEGRATED the table." 
The most commonly marked incorrect answer on the Pretest is _go away,_ perhaps because DISINTEGRATE looks a little like _disappear_. 
Other forms of the word: DISINTEGRATION, n.

SUMMIT.deftext:
the top, highest point, acme 
The SUMMIT is the peak or highest point of something. 
"After hours of climbing they reached the SUMMIT of the mountain." 
"He was at the SUMMIT of his powers when he was struck down by the illness." 
A SUMMIT _talk_ or SUMMIT _meeting_ is a conference of the highest-level officials of governments, such as the president of the United States and the prime minister of Great Britain.

PROFICIENT.deftext:
skillful, expert, adept 
PROFICIENT means _very skilled_ or _expert_ at doing something. The word usually suggests that this skill is the result of training and practice. 
"She worked hard to become a PROFICIENT typist." 
"Bob is very PROFICIENT at gardening. His roses have won prizes." 
"Sally is quite PROFICIENT in the art of making up excuses. She always has one ready when she hasn't done something she's supposed to do." 
The noun from PROFICIENT is PROFICIENCY, which means _skill._ 
"She lacks PROFICIENCY in speaking a foreign language, but otherwise she's perfect for the job." 
Other forms of the word: PROFICIENCY, n.

CHRONIC.deftext:
constant, continual, long-lasting 
CHRONIC comes from the Greek word for _time._ Something that is CHRONIC lasts for a long time without change. The word is used especially about diseases or conditions which are difficult to cure or improve. 
"She has CHRONIC arthritis in her hands and is constantly in pain." 
"The school was hampered by a CHRONIC shortage of money." 
CHRONIC is also used about a person who has a constant habit or disease. 
"He is a CHRONIC complainer. He is always finding fault with something." 
"He has been a CHRONIC cigarette smoker for thirty years." 
The most popular wrong answer on the Pretest is _medical,_ probably because CHRONIC is used so often about diseases. People who choose _medical_ have seen the word CHRONIC used, but haven't been able to narrow it down to its specific meaning.

INDUCE.deftext:
to persuade, influence, prevail upon; to bring about, cause 
To INDUCE someone to do something is to lead or cause him to do it, usually by showing him the advantages that will result. 
"We finally INDUCED him to be quiet by offering him an ice cream cone." 
"Nothing would INDUCE her to enter the haunted house." 
When used about things, INDUCE means to _bring about_ or _cause._ 
"His illness was INDUCED by poison gas." 
"The drug INDUCED a state of sleepiness." 
An INDUCEMENT is something which INDUCES, a _motive_ or _incentive._ 
"We offered to double his salary as an INDUCEMENT for him to join our company." 
Other forms of the word: INDUCEMENT, n.

PUNY.deftext:
feeble, weak, small 
Someone who is PUNY is smaller and weaker than normal. The word is usually used in an insulting manner. PUNY is also used about things and actions, and means _insignificant, petty._ 
"Although very PUNY at birth, the puppy survived to become a champion." 
"His PUNY efforts to entertain the group were a complete flop." 
"They said he was too PUNY to make the football team."

PRECINCT.deftext:
a district, region 
A PRECINCT is an _area_ or _district._ In the United States, PRECINCT is most often used about a particular section of a town or city used for election or administrative purposes. 
"We vote in the twelfth PRECINCT." 
"The policeman worked in the fourth PRECINCT." 
The word is also used in the plural for any area bounded by walls or other limits. 
"You are now within the sacred PRECINCTS of the temple." 
Or the word can mean "the area immediately surrounding a place." 
"The king allowed no commoners in the PRECINCTS of his castle."

CLICHE.deftext:
a trite phrase, worn-out expression 
Note the pronunciation. 
A CLICHE is a phrase or expression which has been used so much that it has become trite, worn out, and stale. 
"His speech was so full of CLICHES that we wondered if he had ever had one original thought." 
"You must try to avoid using CLICHES in your compositions. Think of new ways to express your ideas." 
Some examples of CLICHES are "fresh as a daisy," "last but not least," "pretty as a picture," and "hook, line, and sinker."

SULLEN.deftext:
gloomy, ill-humored, sulky 
Someone who is SULLEN is moody, silent, and often bad-tempered. 
"He was a SULLEN boy who always acted as if you had just insulted him." 
"Jane became very SULLEN when her parents refused to let her go to the party." 
"He gave them a SULLEN look and walked out of the house, slamming the door behind him." 
When used about things, SULLEN means _gloomy_ or _dismal._ 
"The sky was dark and SULLEN. It looked like rain."

PROLOGUE.deftext:
an introduction 
A PROLOGUE is an introduction, especially one that comes before the beginning of a book or a play. See _pro-_ under Prefixes. 
"We recited the PROLOGUE to the Declaration of Independence." 
"Even though this book itself is very interesting, its PROLOGUE is very dull." 
PROLOGUE can also be used loosely about the introduction or first part of something. 
"This small battle was a PROLOGUE to the long war that was about to start." 
Usage: PROLOGUE is sometimes spelled PROLOG.

RELATE.deftext:
to tell; to connect logically 
RELATE is used in two different ways. To RELATE a story or experience is to tell it, to give an account of it. 
"He RELATED how he had come to be president of the company." 
"She RELATED the story of the Headless Horseman." 
To RELATE one thing _to_ another thing is to make or show a connection, or relationship, between them. 
"It is hard to RELATE your results to what we already know." 
In an extended sense, when used about a person RELATE means "to have a meaningful RELATIONSHIP." 
"Helen found that she could RELATE very well to Phil even though he was much older." 
RELATED is an adjective which means _connected._ 
"We didn't know the two events were RELATED until much later." 
People who are RELATED are connected by blood. 
"We are distantly RELATED. She is my third cousin." 
Other forms of the word: RELATED, adj. RELATIONSHIP, n.

INTIMATE.deftext:
very close, personal, private 
INTIMATE is used in several senses, all with the general meaning of _close_, _personal_, _private_. INTIMATE friends are very close, very deep friends. An INTIMATE conversation is a private, personal talk that you would not want to be overheard. A person who has an INTIMATE knowledge of a subject knows it extremely well, is deeply familiar with it. The INTIMATE details of an event or a person's life are the private, secret matters that few people know about. 
"The mechanic had an INTIMATE understanding of how cars work." 
"No one ever learned the INTIMATE secrets of her life." 
Other forms of the word: INTIMACY, n.

questions.prompt: Do people usually get upset when someone CONCURS with them?
Is December the INITIAL month of the year?
Is it against the law to ABDUCT someone?

Can a river BISECT a city?

No one CONCURRED with Jim's opinion that the earth is flat.
Their INITIAL findings were supported by later research.
Jane ABDUCTED to us that we weren't trying hard enough.
Poor people love this senator because he is their leading ADVERSARY in Congress.
The scar on his face is the result of a SABER duel.
Everyone became excited and angry during the ARID debate.
Her long hair fell over her shoulders in beautiful CASCADES.
Jane was so DILIGENT we knew that nothing would get done while she was in charge.
She was terribly upset by the ACCUSATION that she had lied.
The speaker MEANDERED us to the point where we were all bored.
He ENCOMPASSED the dog by letting it run free.
His idea was at such an EMBRYONIC stage that we didn't know if it was any good or not.
Our organization is not AFFILIATED with any other group.
He BISECTED the pie with a knife.
That WRETCH made our lives miserable for years.

CONCUR.deftext:
to agree; to happen together 
To CONCUR with someone is to agree with him, to have the same opinion as he does. 
"Everyone CONCURRED that this was the only action that could be taken." 
"The two of us did not CONCUR in our opinion of the movie." 
CONCUR can also mean "to happen or work together." 
"His father's death and his accident CONCURRED, making it impossible for him to start college this semester." 
The noun from CONCUR is CONCURRENCE, which means _agreement._ 
"With her parents' CONCURRENCE she decided to take a year off from school." 
Other forms of the word: CONCURRENCE, n. CONCURRENT, adj.

INITIAL.deftext:
beginning, first 
INITIAL comes from a Latin word meaning _beginning._ This is also the source of the word _initiate,_ which means to _begin, set going._ INITIAL means "of or at the beginning." 
"My INITIAL feeling was that he was being unfair, but later I changed my mind." 
"His INITIAL act as king was to release all the political prisoners." 
"INITIALLY we opposed the idea, but now we are in favor of it." 
INITIALS are the beginning letters of names. 
"The INITIALS 'U.S.A.' stand for the United States of America."

ABDUCT.deftext:
to kidnap, carry off 
To ABDUCT a person is to carry him off by force and illegally, to _kidnap_ him. 
"Two men ABDUCTED the child and held him for ransom." 
"The rich businessman was ABDUCTED yesterday by three masked men." 
_Harm_ is often chosen as the meaning of ABDUCT in the Pretest. A person who is ABDUCTED may also be _harmed,_ but ABDUCT means only to _kidnap._ Other forms of the word: ABDUCTION, n.

ADVERSARY.deftext:
an enemy, opponent 
An ADVERSARY is an enemy or opponent, someone you fight with or have a contest with. 
"Those two hated each other from the day they met, and they've been ADVERSARIES ever since." 
"Try to be nicer to people; don't act as if everyone were your ADVERSARY." 
"Although the two lawyers often were ADVERSARIES in court, they were the best of friends otherwise." 
People often think an ADVERSARY is a partner, which is almost opposite in meaning.

SABER.deftext:
a sword 
A SABER is a heavy military sword with a curved blade. It is also a fencing or dueling sword. 
"The officer swung his SABER at the advancing enemy." 
"He stood at attention before the general, his SABER at his side." 
"SABER rattling" is a threatening display of military power of any kind. 
"The enemy put thousands of troops on our borders and made insulting speeches about us. This SABER rattling didn't bother us a bit.''

ARID.deftext:
dry, barren, parched 
ARID means "without moisture," _dry._ ARID is usually a somewhat stronger word than _dry._ Something that is ARID is totally dry and lifeless. When used about land, the word means specifically "without enough rainfall to grow crops." 
"Farmers couldn't survive in the ARID regions of the West." 
ARID can also be used in a general sense to mean _lifeless, barren, monotonous._ 
"The book's treatment of history was rather ARID—it was just a listing of dates and names." 
"She fell asleep during the ARID discussion of the rules for the meeting." 
Other forms of the word: ARIDITY, n.

CASCADE.deftext:
a waterfall 
A CASCADE is a fall of water over steep, slanted rocks, as in a river or stream. It is not just a straight fall of water but one that is broken up into a series of stages or steps. 
"Halfway up the mountain we came upon a CASCADE of clear water that rushed over a series of jagged rocks high above us." 
CASCADE can be used about anything that falls or rushes forth in great quantity. 
"The end of the symphony was truly magnificent, with its CASCADE of sound filling every corner of the huge auditorium." 
CASCADE can also be used as a verb meaning "to fall or pour down as if in a waterfall." 
"Yards of gorgeous lace CASCADED down the front of the bridal gown."

DILIGENT.deftext:
hard-working, industrious, tireless 
Someone who is DILIGENT works hard and carefully at something. He doesn't let up or make silly mistakes. 
"We will only hire DILIGENT employees. We want people who will put in a good day's work." 
"They searched DILIGENTLY for the lost ring all day, but finally had to give up." 
"The DILIGENT student did his homework faithfully every night." 
Other forms of the word: DILIGENCE, n.

ACCUSATION.deftext:
a charge 
To ACCUSE a person is to declare that he is guilty of having done something wrong or evil, to charge him with something. 
"The teacher ACCUSED him of stealing the watch." 
"I was ACCUSED of being one of the gang." 
If you are ACCUSED of a crime, it doesn't mean you are guilty. It just means someone thinks you are guilty. 
ACCUSATION is the noun from ACCUSE. It is a _charge,_ a declaration of wrongdoing. 
"There was an ACCUSATION in the newspaper that the mayor had accepted a bribe." 
"He denied all the ACCUSATIONS against him." 
Other forms of the word: ACCUSE, v.

MEANDER.deftext:
to wander, ramble, follow a winding course 
The MEANDER was a river in ancient Asia noted for its winding course. As a verb, MEANDER means to _wander aimlessly,_ without a destination. The word can be used about people, and about things like roads or rivers. 
"The path MEANDERED through the forest." 
"After dinner they MEANDERED through the park for a while." 
"He MEANDERED from town to town, heading nowhere in particular."

ENCOMPASS.deftext:
to include, surround, encircle, envelop 
One meaning of COMPASS is _limits_ or _boundaries._ 
"This subject is well within the COMPASS of our study." 
To ENCOMPASS something is to include it within a particular COMPASS, to _encircle_ or _enclose_ it. 
"These mountains ENCOMPASS the valley." 
"This book ENCOMPASSES the entire history of opera"—that is, the entire history is included in the book. 
"The study of art ENCOMPASSES painting, drawing, and sculpture."

EMBRYONIC.deftext:
undeveloped, immature, rudimentary 
An EMBRYO is an animal in the early stages of its development before birth. The adjective from EMBRYO is EMBRYONIC, which means "like an EMBRYO." See _-ic_ under Suffixes. Since an EMBRYO is very young and undeveloped, EMBRYONIC can apply to anything which is in its earliest stages, which hasn't developed enough to be recognizable. Just as an EMBRYO turns into a mature adult, something which is called EMBRYONIC should be capable of developing into something much larger and more complete. 
"The plans are still EMBRYONIC: it will take us a while to complete them." 
"When the industry was in its EMBRYONIC stages few people realized how important it would become." 
Other forms of the word: EMBRYO, n.

AFFILIATE.deftext:
to ally, associate 
The Latin word _filius_ means _son._ AFFILIATE comes from a Latin word which means "to adopt as a son." In English the word has come to mean "to enter into association" or "to join as a member." AFFILIATE usually suggests a close relationship, but one in which the various people or parts stay at least somewhat separate. 
"Our team tried to AFFILIATE itself with the local softball league." 
"He is not AFFILIATED with any company. He works for himself." 
"The national organization has many local branches AFFILIATED with it." 
AFFILIATE is also a noun. 
"Channel 3 is an AFFILIATE of the CBS television network." 
Other forms of the word: AFFILIATION, n.

BISECT.deftext:
to cut in two, halve, split 
To BISECT something is to cut it into two, usually equal, pieces. The _bi-_ part of the word means _two,_ as in _bicycle_ and _binoculars_. The _-sect_ part means _cut,_ as in _dissect_ (to cut apart) and _intersect_ (to cut across). "The new road will BISECT the town neatly, passing right through the center of it." "The 90° angle was BISECTED to make two 45° angles." 
_Double_ is the most common incorrect answer on the Pretest. People who choose it know that _bi-_ means _two,_ but don't know its special use in BISECT.

WRETCHED.deftext:
miserable, foul, poor 
A WRETCHED person is very unhappy or unlucky. 
"I felt WRETCHED when I woke up this morning, but now I'm somewhat better." 
"This WRETCHED woman has had a hard life." 
A WRETCHED thing is of very poor quality. 
"This book is WRETCHED. It is the worst I've ever read." 
"They live in a WRETCHED shack with no heat or running water." 
A WRETCH is a miserable person, either one who is very unfortunate or one who is very evil. 
"Those poor WRETCHES are doomed to die very soon." 
"Some hateful WRETCH thought it would be fun to burn our house down." 
Other forms of the word: WRETCH, n.

questions.prompt: We DEEM it to be unnecessary.
Do the police usually INSTIGATE crimes?
Would wearing mittens HAMPER a person who is trying to play the guitar?
Do ALLIES fight against each other?
Can someone be BOMBARDED with requests?
Would a "slip of the tongue" be a LAPSE?
Would an IMPOVERISHED area be quite wealthy?
Could a shovel be used in making an EXCAVATION?
If someone DEEMS a book to be terrible, does he dislike it?
Are UNRULY children quiet and well-behaved?
Would it be easy to INFILTRATE a place that was well-guarded?
Do countries practice ESPIONAGE during wartime?
Would most salesmen try to be CIVIL with their customers?
The protest group INSTIGATED the demonstration against the new tax.
He was HAMPERED by his inability to read.
It was only a temporary ALLIANCE; when the battle was over they went back to being enemies.
The company BOMBARDED him with letters demanding that he pay his bills.
After a LAPSE of three years he started to skate again.
We IMPOVERISHED them not to come with us.
They EXCAVATED a tomb that was thousands of years old.
The teacher DEEMED him the best student in the school.
The UNRULY crowd refused to obey the police officers.
He INFILTRATED his father's wallet looking for money.
He had a great sense of HUMILITY; he could make us laugh any time he wanted.
The enemy bribed him to become an ESPIONAGE agent.
The newspaper DISPATCHED a photographer to take pictures of the event.
The soldiers ordered all the CIVILITY to leave the area at once.
He ran his hands over the cold, RAUCOUS sides of the cave.

INSTIGATE.deftext:
to urge on, stir up, goad, incite 
To INSTIGATE is to urge on, usually for some evil purpose. You can INSTIGATE a person. 
"They INSTIGATED the people to riot in the streets." 
Or you can INSTIGATE an action. 
"They INSTIGATED the war by spreading lies about both countries." 
"We must discover who INSTIGATED the plot to murder the king." 
Other forms of the word: INSTIGATION, n. INSTIGATOR, n.

HAMPER.deftext:
to obstruct, block, impede, interfere with, hinder 
To HAMPER something is to hold it back, to make difficulties for it in some way. To HAMPER is not to stop something completely, but simply to make it harder to do or finish. 
"Their opposition HAMPERED our work but couldn't prevent it." 
"The team was HAMPERED by a lack of time to practice." 
"His quick temper doesn't help him on the job; in fact, I think it HAMPERS his effectiveness."

ALLIANCE.deftext:
a union, association, connection 
An ALLIANCE is a union of two or more people or countries who agree to act together for their mutual benefit. 
"The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) is a military ALLIANCE of Western nations." 
"We couldn't understand the sudden ALLIANCE between David and Bob, because they had been unfriendly for years." 
An ALLY is someone who is in a union or association with another. 
"We became ALLIES when we decided that neither of us could win without the other." 
"During World War II, the United States and Great Britain were ALLIES." 
Other forms of the word: ALLY, n., v.

BOMBARD.deftext:
to shell 
BOMBARD comes from the word BOMB and means "to attack with explosive weapons," to _shell._ 
"The enemy troops BOMBARDED the building with hand grenades." 
"The battleships BOMBARDED several towns along the coast." 
BOMBARD can also be used in a more general sense to mean "to attack vigorously." 
"The teacher was BOMBARDED with questions about the final exam." 
"The sanitation department was BOMBARDED with complaints when its workers went on strike." 
BOMBARDMENT is the act of BOMBARDING. 
"The entire city was a mass of crumbling ruins as a result of the BOMBARDMENT by enemy aircraft." 
Other forms of the word: BOMBARDMENT, n.

LAPSE.deftext:
a slight error, slip; a fall, decline; a passing of time 
LAPSE comes from a Latin word meaning to _fall,_ also the source of the words _collapse, relapse,_ and _elapse._ LAPSE is used in several different senses. A LAPSE is a slight mistake or slip. 
"There were a few LAPSES in his performance, but overall it was quite good." 
"He had a sudden memory LAPSE and could not recall his friend's name." 
A LAPSE is also a falling or decline to a lower degree or standard. 
"After they behaved well all day there was a brief LAPSE into their former rudeness." 
It is also a period of time that has passed, an interval. 
"There was a LAPSE of ten minutes before they started the show again."

IMPOVERISH.deftext:
to make poor, reduce to poverty 
IMPOVERISH comes from the Latin word for poor, also the source of the English word _poverty._ To IMPOVERISH someone is to make him very poor. 
"The Depression IMPOVERISHED many families." 
You can IMPOVERISH something by removing its strength, richness, or other good qualities. 
"This town will be IMPOVERISHED by the loss of these two fine men." 
"The soil was IMPOVERISHED by planting the same crops year after year." 
IMPOVERISH is often used in the form of an adjective, IMPOVERISHED. 
"The IMPOVERISHED farmers asked for loans so that they could keep their land." 
Other forms of the word: IMPOVERISHED, adj.

EXCAVATE.deftext:
to dig out, hollow out, unearth 
See _ex-_ under Prefixes and _-ate1_ under Suffixes. To EXCAVATE something is to make a _cave_ out of it, to hollow it out, to remove the earth from it. 
"They EXCAVATED a large area for the foundation of the building." 
"WE EXCAVATED a long tunnel through the mountain." 
EXCAVATE is also used in a slightly different sense, to mean "to uncover by digging." 
"The archaeologists EXCAVATED the ancient city, which had been buried for thousands of years." 
An EXCAVATION is the act of EXCAVATING, or the hole made by EXCAVATING. 
"They examined the entire EXCAVATION before allowing the engineers to complete the tunnel." 
Other forms of the word: EXCAVATION, n.

DEEM.deftext:
to consider, believe, think 
DEEM means "to have as an opinion," to _consider_ or _believe._ 
"They DEEM him the best person for the job." 
"I DEEM it best that I continue in school rather than go to work right away." 
"She DEEMS it her duty to help." 
Usage: DEEM is a rather formal word, and would not be used often in ordinary conversation.

UNRULY.deftext:
wild, disorderly, uncontrollable 
The basic meaning of UNRULY is "not obeying the rules." See _un-_ under Prefixes. Usually the word is applied to people who are wild or difficult to control. 
"After two hours of sitting quietly and listening to the speech, the children started to become UNRULY." 
"The UNRULY mob shouted and jeered at the policemen who were trying to keep order." 
"These children are not evil, just excited and UNRULY." 
Many people think UNRULY means _angry._ The two words are close in meaning, but someone could be disorderly without being _angry._

INFILTRATE.deftext:
to pass into or through by filtering 
A _filter_ is an article or substance which allows certain things to pass through it and keeps out others. A cigarette filter, for example, lets smoke through but keeps out some impurities from the tobacco. 
To INFILTRATE is to pass into something through a filter, or as if through a filter. See _in-1_ under Prefixes and _-ate1_ under Suffixes. The word is often used about soldiers entering enemy territory in small groups through weak points in the enemy defenses. 
"The general decided to INFILTRATE enemy territory rather than to launch a full-scale attack." 
INFILTRATE is used generally about people entering someplace or something secretly. 
"The FBI agent INFILTRATED the terrorist group." 
"He believed the organization had been INFILTRATED by Communist spies." 
Other forms of the word: INFILTRATION, n.

HUMILITY.deftext:
modesty, lack of pride 
HUMILITY comes from the adjective HUMBLE. A HUMBLE person has a low or modest opinion of himself, is not proud or self-important. HUMILITY is the quality of being HUMBLE. See _-ity_ under Suffixes. 
"Her HUMILITY was genuine. She really didn't think she was very important." 
"We all felt greater HUMILITY after meeting this brilliant and saintly man." 
"With deep HUMILITY he said that other people deserved the award more than he."

ESPIONAGE.deftext:
adj.: spying, the use of spies 
ESPIONAGE is from a French word meaning to _spy._ ESPIONAGE is _spying,_ the secret observation of people, governments, and the like. 
"The Russians accused him of ESPIONAGE." 
"They set up a large network of ESPIONAGE agents." 
ESPIONAGE can be used about the actual spying itself, or the general system of using spies to collect information. 
"Their ESPIONAGE system was good at uncovering information but bad at understanding it."

DISPATCH.deftext:
to send, send away; to get through or done; to kill 
To DISPATCH something is to send it away, usually quickly or for a special purpose. See _dis-_ under Prefixes. 
"He DISPATCHED a telegram reporting the king's death." 
"The police DISPATCHED a patrol car to the scene of the robbery." 
The word can also mean "to get through quickly" and is used about things like work or food. 
"He DISPATCHED the first job in under an hour and started immediately on the second." 
In a special sense, DISPATCH can also mean to _kill,_ especially rapidly and efficiently. "The executioner DISPATCHED him with one blow of the ax." 
Usage: DISPATCH is sometimes spelled DESPATCH.

CIVILITY.deftext:
politeness, courtesy 
To be CIVIL is to be polite. The word often suggests merely adequate politeness rather than great courtesy. 
"It was all he could do to be CIVIL with the rude customers." 
CIVILITY is the state of being CIVIL, _politeness._ See _-ity_ under Suffixes. 
"She greeted the stranger with CIVILITY but without enthusiasm." 
"We admired his CIVILITY toward people he hated." 
CIVILITIES, the plural form, are polite acts or expressions. 
"The two men exchanged CIVILITIES and then got quickly down to work." 
_Patience_ is the most commonly chosen incorrect answer. CIVILITY might include _patience,_ but the two words aren't synonyms. Other forms of the word: CIVIL, adj.

RAUCOUS.deftext:
harsh, hoarse, grating 
RAUCOUS is used mainly about sounds. The word means "disagreeably loud and harsh." It often suggests that this loud noise is the result of disorderly behavior. 
"We listened to the RAUCOUS noise of the crows outside our window." 
"The neighbors complained about the RAUCOUS party across the hall." 
"The RAUCOUS laughter stopped suddenly when the teacher entered the room." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer on the Pretest is deep. _Deep_ can also be used about sounds and voices, but deep sounds are not always loud and grating.

questions.prompt: Could a parking lot be a RENDEZVOUS?
Would a RESOLUTE person change his mind often?
Is everyone allowed to see a movie that is RESTRICTED?
Is mountain climbing usually an ILLICIT action?
Is a SARCASTIC person usually lovable?
Would most people be STUPEFIED if they were given a check for a million dollars?
Would staying up all night INVIGORATE most people?
Does a man who tries for ten years to get through college show PERSERVERANCE
Can an aroma WAFT into a room?
Would a person who hasn't slept for days usually look HAGGARD?
Would a VAGABOND like to hold a steady job?
Would a strong habit be INGRAINED in a person?
Is it likely that a lazy person would be RELENTLESS in pursuing a job?
We all arranged to RENDEZVOUS at midnight in the old barn.
It was RESOLUTE that they would go to the beach this weekend.
She RESTRICTED them that smoking was not allowed here.
The police charged him with the ILLICIT sale of liquor.
She was very SARCASTIC to go into the house by herself.
The MINUSCULE church towered above the houses in the area.
I was STUPEFIED to find out that I had actually won first prize in the contest.
The knowledge that he was almost finished INVIGORATED him and kept him going.
Even if you are not successful at first, you must PERSEVERE.
The sound of the beautiful music WAFTED across the lake.
He looked very HAGGARD after running the marathon.
John is very PLIANT. He will go along with whatever the rest of the group wants.
Each summer the students became VAGABONDS, roaming through the countryside and having a good time.
She has practiced that piece on the piano for so long that it has become INGRAINED in her mind.
She RELENTED him severely for not trying.

RENDEZVOUS.deftext:
a meeting, meeting-place 
Note the pronunciation. RENDEZVOUS comes from a French phrase which means "Present yourselves." A RENDEZVOUS is a place where people arrange to meet. The word is often used as a military term for the place where ships or troops are to assemble. 
"I'll meet you at four o'clock at the RENDEZVOUS." 
A RENDEZVOUS can also be the meeting itself. 
"We arranged a RENDEZVOUS for four o'clock." 
"I had a RENDEZVOUS with them at the restaurant." 
RENDEZVOUS is also a verb. 
"We will RENDEZVOUS at the usual place." 
On the Pretest, many people select _journey_ as the synonym for RENDEZVOUS, perhaps because you have to travel to reach a RENDEZVOUS.

RESOLUTE.deftext:
determined, firm, resolved 
One meaning of the word RESOLVE is to _decide_ or _determine._ 
"He RESOLVED that he would be famous by age thirty." 
RESOLUTE is the adjective from RESOLVE, and is used about people. Someone who is RESOLUTE is firm and determined in a course of action or belief. 
"The senators were RESOLUTE in their opposition to the bill." 
"The RESOLUTE men said that if it was necessary they would wait all day to see him." 
"He stood RESOLUTE against all the enemies of the nation." 
Other forms of the word: RESOLUTION,n. RESOLVE,v.

RESTRICT.deftext:
to limit, restrain 
To RESTRICT means "to put limits on, to keep within bounds." The word is used about both people and things. 
"Their parents RESTRICT them to one cookie for dessert." 
"Bicycles are RESTRICTED to certain paths in the park." 
"His speech was largely RESTRICTED to the topic of international trade." 
_Stop_ is often chosen as the meaning of RESTRICT,but you can RESTRICT something without entirely _stopping_ it. 
"The sale of alcohol is RESTRICTED to persons over eighteen years of age." 
Other forms of the word: RESTRICTION,n.

ILLICIT.deftext:
unlawful, not allowed, not permitted 
_Licit_ is a rather rare word which means _legal, lawful._ It comes from a Latin word meaning "It is allowed." ILLICIT is the opposite of _licit._ It means "not allowed," _unlawful, illegal._ See _in-2_ under Prefixes. 
"The ILLICIT sale of drugs is a major problem." 
"The company was accused of ILLICIT business practices."

SARCASTIC.deftext:
biting, caustic, ironical 
SARCASTIC and its noun SARCASM come from a Greek word meaning "to tear flesh,to bite one's lips in rage, thus to sneer." SARCASM is biting language, remarks that hurt by making fun of someone or something. 
"No one liked him because he always treated everyone with SARCASM." 
SARCASTIC means "full of SARCASM," and is used about people and the things they say or do. 
"He was a SARCASTIC fellow, always ready to insult people. " 
"The teacher's SARCASTIC remarks made the little girl cry." 
Other forms of the word: SARCASM,n.

MINUSCULE.deftext:
tiny, very small, insignificant 
Note the spelling. Many people think the word begins with _mini-._ MINUSCULE comes from the word _minus_, and means _very small_, _tiny_. 
"The painting is MINUSCULE. You need a magnifying glass just to see it." 
"He made up for his MINUSCULE size by being extremely quick and clever." 
MINUSCULE as a noun has a specific meaning, referring to small letters in printing as opposed to capital letters.

STUPEFY.deftext:
to stun, astonish 
When something STUPEFIES you, it is so amazing or frightening or powerful that it takes away your senses and leaves you confused and dazed. 
"We were all STUPEFIED by the news that all along our friend had actually been an enemy spy." 
"Her announcement STUPEFIED me. I didn't know what to do or say next." 
"The movie was STUPEFYINGLY dull"—that is, it was so dull that it would almost put you to sleep.

INVIGORATE.deftext:
to strengthen, refresh, enliven 
See _in-1_ under Prefixes and _-ate1_ under Suffixes. _Vigor_ is strength, energy, active good health. 
"After a good night's sleep she awoke refreshed and full of vigor." 
To INVIGORATE is to fill with _vigor._ 
"Just breathing that nice fresh air is enough to INVIGORATE me." 
"The new members tried to INVIGORATE the club by organizing all sorts of activities." 
Other forms of the word: INVIGORATING, adj.

PERSEVERE.deftext:
to persist, keep on, continue 
To PERSEVERE in something is to keep at it, especially in the face of difficulty or opposition. The word usually suggests that this is a good quality, that the person who PERSEVERES should be praised for not giving up. 
"I know things are hard for us now, but I'm sure if we PERSEVERE they will improve in the end." 
"The course was difficult, but he PERSEVERED in his studies, and finally he passed." 
"Despite her parents' opposition, she PERSEVERED in trying to become a doctor." 
PERSEVERANCE is steady persistence. 
"You must have PERSEVERANCE if you want to become a top athlete, because it takes years of training and practice." 
Other forms of the word: PERSEVERANCE, n.

WAFT.deftext:
to move lightly and smoothly, float 
To WAFT is to move or carry lightly and smoothly, usually through the air or on water. WAFT can be used about smells and sounds as well as physical objects. 
"The breeze WAFTED the smell of roses into the room." 
"A leaf WAFTED gently to the ground." 
"The gentle waves WAFTED her ball slowly out to sea." 
"The distant shouts of children playing WAFTED in through the open window."

HAGGARD.deftext:
having a worn, tired appearance; gaunt 
Someone who is HAGGARD looks tired and worn out from worry, lack of sleep, lack of food, or the like. His eyes might be bloodshot, his face might be thin and lined, his clothing might be rumpled. 
"After losing his job, he came home looking HAGGARD and discouraged." 
"She felt sorry for the beggar when she saw his dirty clothes and HAGGARD face." 
"He looked HAGGARD after waiting at the hospital all night."

PLIANT.deftext:
easily bent, flexible, yielding, adaptable 
PLIANT comes from a Latin word meaning to bend. Something that is PLIANT can be bent easily without breaking. 
"The wax was very PLIANT and could be easily molded or shaped." 
When used about people, PLIANT means "easily influenced, open to suggestions." 
"Our boss proved to be quite PLIANT and agreed to all our requests." 
"The PLIANT students did whatever the teacher told them to do." 
"Our father isn't PLIANT at all. We can never make him change his mind." 
PLIANT is close in meaning to a very similar word, _pliable,_ which also means "easily bent or influenced."

VAGABOND.deftext:
a wanderer, tramp, hobo 
A VAGABOND is a person with no home, a carefree wanderer who never settles down. The word usually suggests the pleasures of this kind of life rather than the problems. 
"He was a happy VAGABOND, traveling here and there, wherever he pleased." 
"The life of a VAGABOND seems very appealing to one who is stuck in a dull job." 
VAGABOND is also used as an adjective, meaning _wandering._ 
"We went on a VAGABOND tour of Europe."

INGRAINED.deftext:
deep-rooted, deeply fixed 
See _in-1_ under Prefixes. One meaning of _grain_ is "the natural appearance and texture of wood." Something which is INGRAINED is not just on the surface but worked into the _grain._ The word is particularly used about beliefs or characteristics that are deeply rooted in a person or group. 
"Almost always, habits and prejudices are deeply INGRAINED." 
"His INGRAINED honesty kept him from even considering taking a bribe." 
Other forms of the word: INGRAIN, v.

RELENT.deftext:
to give in, yield 
To RELENT is to become less harsh, to let up or give in. The word is usually used about people. 
"The teacher finally RELENTED and told Bill he didn't have to stay after school." 
"She begged her mother to let her go to the dance, but her mother wouldn't RELENT." 
"When he saw her crying, he RELENTED and let her keep the toy." 
Someone who is RELENTLESS does not or cannot RELENT, is harsh and persistent. 
"They begged him to stop teasing the child, but he was RELENTLESS." 
Other forms of the word: RELENTLESS, adj.

questions.prompt: Would a person who lost his temper every ten minutes lack COMPOSURE?
Does a PROPHECY deal with future events?

We all listened to the musician's beautiful COMPOSURE.

Because of his bad back they EXEMPTED him from physical work.
His MAGISTERIAL tone prompted us to obey him.
Several MARINERS were drowned when the ship sank.
Everyone was stunned by the APPALLING news that the earthquake had destroyed the town.
The crowd EMITTED a cheer as the fireworks went off.
The player PETITIONED the school to let him rejoin the team.
He MERITED his opponent by three points in the match.
His years of study and writing had made him an EMINENT authority in his field.
She YIELDED to the child's demands and let him stay up later.
Tom may be only a NOVICE, but he's good learner and should improve quickly.
Their constant JOCULARITY kept the meeting from being a very serious one.
Andy had a HARROWING dream in which his house caught fire.

COMPOSURE.deftext:
calmness, self-possession 
The verb COMPOSE has several different meanings. One has to do with mental states, and means to _calm_ or _get under control._ 
"It took him a while to COMPOSE himself after he almost had an accident." 
COMPOSURE is the noun from this meaning of COMPOSE. 
"She managed to keep her COMPOSURE despite the intense pressure of the job." 
"The witness lost his COMPOSURE and started shouting when the lawyer accused him of being a liar." 
Other forms of the word: COMPOSE,v. COMPOSED,adj.

PROPHECY.deftext:
a prediction, foretelling 
A PROPHECY is a prediction of what will happen in the future. People who have the power of PROPHECY are supposed to be able to tell what is going to happen. 
"She made several PROPHECIES about events in the coming year." 
"His PROPHECY that the farmers would suffer a terrible drought did not come true." 
A PROPHET is someone who makes PROPHECIES. To PROPHESY is to make a PROPHECY. Notice the difference in spelling. 
"He PROPHESIED that the world would come to an end,but no one believed his PROPHECY." 
Other forms of the word: PROPHESY,v. PROPHET,n. PROPHETIC,adj.

EXEMPT.deftext:
to grant freedom (from a duty), release, excuse 
To EXEMPT someone is to release him from a duty which others have to carry out or a burden which others have to bear. The word is usually applied to legal obligations. 
"They EXEMPTED him from military service because of his poor eyesight." 
"Why was she EXEMPTED from paying taxes?" 
EXEMPT is also used as an adjective. 
"Persons EXEMPT from the draft had to perform some kind of alternate service." 
"We thought the camera was EXEMPT from customs duties." 
Other forms of the word: EXEMPTION,n. 
Usage: EXEMPT is usually used with from.

MAGISTERIAL.deftext:
commanding, authoritative 
See _-al_ under Suffixes. MAGISTERIAL comes from the Latin word for _master_ or _teacher._ MAGISTERIAL means "like a master" and refers to the authority and air of command that a master of something would show. 
"He had a MAGISTERIAL attitude that suggested he was used to giving orders instead of receiving them." 
The word is often used in a negative sense, suggesting that this air of command is rather overbearing. 
"He spoke in a MAGISTERIAL tone, as if his were the only opinions worth hearing."

MARINER.deftext:
a sailor, seaman 
See _-er_ under Suffixes. MARINER comes from _mare,_ the Latin word for sea and also the source of the word _marine._ A MARINER is someone who sails the sea, a _sailor._ The word is particularly used about someone who navigates or assists in navigating a ship. 
On the Pretest, many people think MARINER means _swimmer._ These people know that MARINER has something to do with the sea, but aren't sure what. 
Usage: MARINER is a literary word and would not often be used in ordinary speech.

APPALLING.deftext:
horrifying, frightful, dreadful, shocking 
The verb APPALL is related to the word _pale._ Something that APPALLS you shocks or horrifies you so much that you turn pale. 
"The news of the president's assassination APPALLED everyone." 
Something that is APPALLING fills you with emotions that may range from horror to dismay, usually because it is so bad or unpleasant. 
"The disaster was APPALLING: over seven thousand people died." 
"The dog got loose while the family was out and made an APPALLING mess in the house." 
"Mary showed an APPALLING lack of manners when she slammed the door in the woman's face." 
Other forms of the word: APPALL, v.

EMIT.deftext:
to send out, send forth, throw off, utter 
See _ex-_ under Prefixes. EMIT means to _send out._ The word is often used about light, heat, and sound. 
"The fire EMITS a great deal of smoke." 
"The loudspeaker EMITS an awful noise." 
EMIT is also used about words, orders, and opinions. 
"The crowd EMITTED a groan." 
The word is not usually used about people. You would not say: 
"The policeman EMITTED the trespassers." 
EMIT can easily be confused with _admit,_ although the two words are just about opposites in meaning. EMIT is to send out; _admit_ is to let in. A restaurant would not want to _admit_ a customer who might EMIT a lot of loud noise. 
Other forms of the word: EMISSION, n.

PETITION.deftext:
an appeal, formal request 
A PETITION is an _appeal_ or _request,_ usually a formal written request asking for something from someone in power. 
"All the students signed a PETITION asking the school committee not to fire the teacher." 
"The mayor listened to their PETITION for more police and agreed to look into the matter." 
PETITION is also a verb. 
"The mother PETITIONED the king to release her son from prison." 
"The prisoner PETITIONED the court for a new trial."

VILE.deftext:
wretched, disgusting, foul 
A person or thing that is VILE is disgustingly evil. 
"The police called it one of the VILEST crimes they had ever seen." 
VILE is also used about things that are disgustingly filthy or low. 
"The VILE conditions and VILE smell in the restaurant's kitchen shocked everyone." 
"When he was upset his language would become VILE and he would curse everyone and everything." 
VILE is a very strong word and should be used about people or things that are almost unspeakably bad. 
The most popular wrong answer is _dangerous._ VILE conditions are not necessarily _dangerous._ They are certainly foul and wretched.

MERIT.deftext:
to deserve, earn, be worthy of 
To MERIT something is to deserve or be worthy of it. 
"This painting MERITS first prize." 
"Her suggestion MERITS careful consideration." 
"His criticism of Jane was MERITED. She really was rude." 
MERIT is also a noun, meaning _worth_ or _excellence._ 
"His plan has great MERIT, but it isn't perfect." 
"He got that job by MERIT, not because he knew someone." 
The most commonly chosen incorrect answer is _win._ You can _win_ something without having MERITED it, though, and you can MERIT something without _winning_ it. "We thought he MERITED first prize, but he only came in third." 
Other forms of the word: MERITORIOUS, adj.

EMINENT.deftext:
distinguished, prominent, outstanding, noteworthy 
The basic meaning of EMINENT is "standing out." EMINENT is related to the word _mountain,_ and is sometimes used about actual physical size. Usually,though,the word is used about people and it means "standing above others in quality or fame." 
"Even the most EMINENT physicians couldn't discover what was wrong with him." 
"The EMINENT author spoke about the future of the novel." 
When used about qualities, EMINENT means _remarkable_ or _conspicuous._ 
"Everyone praised the EMINENT fairness of the judge's decision." 
Other forms of the word: EMINENCE,n.

YIELD.deftext:
give, give up, give way The basic meaning of YIELD is to _give_ or _give up._ The word is used in a wide variety of senses. When a tree YIELDS fruit,it gives or produces it. When a car YIELDS to another,it gives way so that the other one can go first. An enemy who YIELDS gives up or surrenders. To YIELD to temptation is to give in to it. 
"The door YIELDED when she pushed against it." 
"The teacher YIELDED to their request and called off the test." 
YIELD is also a noun. 
"That one bush has a YIELD of ten pounds of berries."

NOVICE.deftext:
a beginner, inexperienced person 
NOVICE comes from the Latin word for _new,_ also the source of the words _novel_ and _novelty._ A NOVICE is a person who is new at doing something, _a beginner._ The word was first used about someone who has just entered a religious order, but is now used about any inexperienced beginner. 
"She is just a NOVICE at playing the piano, so don't expect her to be very good." 
"He can type very well for a NOVICE."

JOCULAR.deftext:
humorous, merry, jolly JOCULAR is related to the word _joke._ A JOCULAR person likes to make jokes. He is jolly and enjoys keeping other people amused. 
"The JOCULAR teacher kept the students laughing while they learned." 
JOCULAR words or actions are said or done as a joke. 
"The speaker started off with some JOCULAR remarks to put his audience in a good mood.
" The noun from JOCULAR is JOCULARITY, which is the quality of being humorous and jolly. 
"His JOCULARITY was quite out of place on such a solemn occasion." 
Other forms of the word: JOCULARITY, n.

HARROWING.deftext:
distressing, agonizing, painful, frightening 
A HARROW is a farming tool which cuts into and levels off ground. To HARROW something is to draw a HARROW over it. The word has come to mean to _distress_ or _disturb_ a person as if he were being cut into by a HARROW. HARROWING is the adjective from this meaning of HARROW. It means _distressing, painful,_ especially to the mind or the feelings. 
"Being attacked by the bear was a HARROWING experience." 
"He told us a HARROWING tale of torture and suffering." 
Other forms of the word: HARROW,n.,v.
