questions.prompt: Can old age ENFEEBLE a person?
Would an apprentice have a PROFOUND knowledge of his trade?
Would most people be CRESTFALLEN if they became rich?
Do you EXALT someone by insulting him?
Would the idea of catching a disease ALLURE many people?
Would people be friendly during an AMICABLE discussion?
Is a scream a GUTTURAL sound?
Is it FOLLY to try to pass another car on a curve?
Can a child ANNUL a marriage?
Would a vain person FLAUNT his knowledge?
Can manufacturers make plastics to SIMULATE wood?
Would people approve of someone who ENCROACHED upon their rights?
His words of encouragement ENFEEBLED her to try again.
He told us about his PROFOUND regret that he had never gone to college.
The CRESTFALLEN players realized they just hadn't been good enough to beat the other team.
The emperor was friendly despite his EXALTED position.
The wedding was a REGAL affair that would have pleased any king or queen.
The ALLURE of gold has caused many men to become prospectors.
They both decided they couldn't work together, so they parted AMICABLY.
She gave a high, GUTTURAL giggle and said she was only kidding.
Ed was FOLLY about model railroads. He would play with them all day.
It is hard to CONVEY to you how important I think this subject is.
The Supreme Court ANNULLED the agreement, stating that the president didn't have the power to enter into it.
He had a PREMONITION afterwards that he had done poorly on the test.
She got an A in every subject and FLAUNTED her report card in front of her classmates.
The students SIMULATED an understanding of what the teacher was saying, but it really wasn't clear to them.
The thieves ENCROACHED her pocketbook in broad daylight.

ENFEEBLE.deftext:
to cause extreme weakness, make feeble 
FEEBLE means _very weak, lacking strength._ The prefix _en-_ means "to cause to be," as in _enslave,_ "to cause to be a slave." So ENFEEBLE means "to cause to be FEEBLE." 
"The long illness ENFEEBLED him." 
"The animals were ENFEEBLED by lack of food." 
On the Pretest, many people think ENFEEBLE means _strengthen,_ which is opposite in meaning. This may be due to a confusion of the prefix _en-_ with _un-_ or _in-,_ both of which can mean _not._

PROFOUND.deftext:
deep 
The basic meaning of PROFOUND is _very deep._ The word is sometimes used about physical depth, but it is usually used about interests, ideas, feelings, and the like. PROFOUND often suggests depth of knowledge or wisdom. 
"It was very difficult to awaken him from his PROFOUND sleep." 
"My father has a PROFOUND interest in painting." 
"The author showed a PROFOUND understanding of the way governments work." 
Other forms of the word: PROFUNDITY, n.

CRESTFALLEN.deftext:
discouraged, dejected, disappointed 
A _crest_ is the tuft of feathers on the top of a bird's head. The basic meaning of CRESTFALLEN is "with the crest drooping or falling"—that is, with the head hanging down. From this the word has come to mean "so disappointed, dejected, or discouraged that you want to hang your head." 
"Jim was CRESTFALLEN when he heard he hadn't made the team." 
"Sally will be CRESTFALLEN if she doesn't get a new bicycle for Christmas." 
"The boss told the CRESTFALLEN workers that he couldn't afford to give them a raise."

EXALT.deftext:
to raise high, elevate, glorify 
EXALT comes from the Latin word for _high,_ also the source for the word _altitude._ To EXALT someone is to make him higher, usually in rank, power, or dignity. 
"They EXALTED her by calling her the greatest writer of our time." 
"In his EXALTED position he has little time for these little problems." 
The most common mistake on the Pretest is choosing _thrown out_ as the meaning of EXALTED. This may be due to confusion about the _ex-_ at the beginning of the word, which often means _out of._ Other forms of the word: EXALTATION, n.

REGAL.deftext:
royal, kingly 
See _-al_ under Suffixes. REGAL comes from the Latin word for _king,_ and means "belonging to or like a king." The word often suggests the splendor and magnificence associated with a king. 
"The king was dressed in all his REGAL splendor for this occasion." 
"He was disguised as a beggar, but his REGAL attitude gave him away." 
"They had a REGAL feast to celebrate their great victory."

ALLURE.deftext:
to attract, entice, charm 
ALLURE is related to the word _lure,_ and the two words have similar meanings. To ALLURE someone is to attract him with the offer of something valuable or pleasing. 
"The salesman ALLURED us with tales of fabulous wealth if we bought this stock." 
"The hope of becoming a movie star ALLURES many young women to Hollywood." 
As a noun, ALLURE is this power of attraction, _charm._ 
"The job offer lacked sufficient ALLURE to tempt her." 
"The city of Paris holds quite an ALLURE for many tourists." Other forms of the word: ALLUREMENT, n. ALLURING, adj.

AMICABLE.deftext:
friendly, peaceable, neighborly 
AMICABLE is used about people's actions or attitudes and means "showing good will," _friendly._ AMICABLE is not a very strong word. It usually doesn't suggest deep affection, but merely shows that people aren't disposed to quarrel with one another. 
"Both parties seemed eager for an AMICABLE settlement of their dispute." 
"The two countries maintained AMICABLE relations despite their disagreements." 
"We solved our differences AMICABLY and continued to work together."

GUTTURAL.deftext:
of the throat. 
Note the spelling. The word is spelled with _ur,_ not _er,_ in the middle. GUTTURAL comes from the Latin word for _throat_ and means "related to the throat." The word is usually used about sounds that are produced in the throat and suggests a harsh, unpleasant quality. 
"The sound of the _ch_ in _acht,_ the German word for 'eight,' is a GUTTURAL sound"—that is, it is formed in the throat, not the mouth.

FOLLY.deftext:
foolishness, silliness 
FOLLY means _foolishness, silliness, lack of wisdom._ The word often suggests that this foolishness might have bad consequences. 
"Attempting to swim the Atlantic Ocean was an act of FOLLY." 
"It was FOLLY to ask the boss for a raise." 
FOLLY has been used about a particular event, place, or building. For example, when Secretary of State Seward advised President Lincoln to purchase Alaska, Alaska became known as "Seward's FOLLY" because it was thought that nothing valuable existed there, and its purchase was just a waste of money. It is FOLLY to judge the value of a purchase too quickly.

CONVEY.deftext:
to carry, deliver, transport; to communicate, make known 
To CONVEY something is to carry it from one place to another. 
"This pipe CONVEYS water from the well to the house." 
"Telegraph signals are CONVEYED from one town to another by wires." 
CONVEY is also used about ideas, information, and feelings and means to _make known,_ either directly or indirectly. 
"He CONVEYED his approval by nodding and smiling." 
"We wish to CONVEY our deepest sympathy to you on the death of your father." 
A CONVEYANCE is something that carries or transports, a _vehicle._ 
"No public CONVEYANCES were operating during the snowstorm." 
Other forms of the word: CONVEYANCE, n.

ANNUL.deftext:
to cancel, nullify, make void 
ANNUL comes from the Latin word _nullus,_ which means "none." _Nullus_ is also the source of the words _null_ and _nullify._ To ANNUL something is to make it cease to exist, to put an end to it. The word is most often used about legal agreements. To ANNUL a marriage is to declare that it is not legally valid. 
"The judge ANNULLED the contract between the two companies." 
ANNUL is also sometimes used in other areas as well. 
"Nothing could ANNUL the startling effect of her sudden appearance in the room."

PREMONITION.deftext:
a forewarning, feeling of trouble coming, foreboding 
See _pre-_ under Prefixes. A PREMONITION is a feeling that something, usually bad, is going to happen. There is no conscious reason for this feeling; it just seems to occur. 
"She had a PREMONITION of the accident." 
"Sam didn't pay attention to his PREMONITION that there was danger ahead." 
"He keeps having strange PREMONITIONS, but none of them seem to come true."

FLAUNT.deftext:
to show off, display, wave defiantly, attract attention to 
To FLAUNT something is to show it off, to attract attention to it by displaying it or waving it around. 
"He didn't try to hide his bad habits. He FLAUNTED them in front of everyone." 
"Knowing they couldn't catch him, the boy FLAUNTED the stolen wallet at them." FLAUNT is very often confused with _flout,_ a word which sounds almost the same but has a very different meaning. To _flout_ something is to treat it with contempt, to scoff at it. 
"He thinks we're stupid; he's always _flouting_ our advice." 
To FLAUNT is to show off; to _flout_ is to treat with contempt.

SIMULATE.deftext:
to pretend, pretend to be, imitate 
SIMULATE is related to the word _similar._ To SIMULATE something is to take on its appearance, to pretend to be or have it. 
"The fake fur SIMULATES the appearance and feel of real mink." 
"John SIMULATED lameness so that people would think he was injured." 
"Jane SIMULATED considerable reluctance to take the job, although she really was quite eager." 
"SIMULATED diamonds are much less valuable than real ones." 
Other forms of the word: SIMULATION, n.

ENCROACH.deftext:
to intrude, trespass, enter or take gradually  
To ENCROACH on or upon something is to advance farther than you are supposed to into it, to _trespass_ on it. The word is used about trespassing on actual physical property, and also on things like rights and time. 
"That new fence you built ENCROACHES on my property." 
"Your speech is too long. It will ENCROACH on my time to speak." 
ENCROACH is used especially when this trespassing happens gradually or secretly. 
"Step by step the government started to ENCROACH on their rights." 
"As the years went by the sea ENCROACHED more and more on the land." 
Other forms of the word: ENCROACHMENT, n. 
Usage: ENCROACH is usually followed by on or upon.

questions.prompt: Would a person whose nerves are TAUT be calm?
Is it difficult to hear someone in a HUBBUB?
Can PITEOUS sights make a person cry?
Should a boxer be MEEK when he's fighting?
Is it easy to go through a LABYRINTH?
If people ACCLAIM something do they like it?
Does TOIL often tire people out?
Do butterflies REVERT to being caterpillars?
Could an earthquake OBLITERATE a city?
Are a soldier's medals a part of his ARMAMENT?
If a woman is very beautiful, is she LITERALLY a goddess?
Do people TARRY when they have to get somewhere quickly?
They could hear animals BELLOWING in the jungle.
The dog pulled his chain so TAUT that he started to choke.
She went on her vacation to a quiet HUBBUB in the woods.
The children cried PITEOUSLY as the soldiers took their father away.
Don't be so MEEK. If you think you're right, say so.
The palace was a LABYRINTH of secret passages and hidden staircases.
I was HEARTENED by your kind words.
The man ACCLAIMED the money was his because he had found it.
They TOILED for many years to build the church.
Bob narrowly REVERTED being injured when the stairs collapsed.
The falling snow quickly OBLITERATED all traces of the horse's tracks.
The government spends a great deal of the tax money it collects for ARMAMENTS.
He prepared a LITERAL translation of the play, so that people would know exactly how it went in the original Spanish.
He stood there like a SIMPLETON, with a stupid grin on his face.
Joan TARRIED to the store to get there before it closed.

BELLOW.deftext:
to roar 
To BELLOW is to make a loud, deep sound like a bull. 
"The cattle BELLOWED with fear." 
"The sergeant BELLOWED out some orders to the men." 
"The drunken man BELLOWED with laughter at anything that happened." 
BELLOW is also a noun. 
"We heard the BELLOW of the angry bull." 
Many people select _groan_ as the meaning of BELLOW. To _groan_ is to make a deep sound which indicates pain or sorrow. A BELLOW is also deep, but it is much louder and is done in other situations besides pain and sorrow.

TAUT.deftext:
tense, tight, stretched tightly 
TAUT means _tense_ or _tightly stretched._ Anything like wire, rope, or chains can be pulled TAUT. 
"Keep that cable TAUT; if the tension falls off, we'll have an accident." 
"If the wire is too TAUT it will snap under the strain." 
TAUT is also used about mental tension. 
"Her nerves were TAUT and strained after the hours of waiting."

HUBBUB.deftext:
confused noise, uproar, din; turmoil, confusion 
A HUBBUB is a mixture of loud sounds and voices, an _uproar_ 
"She couldn't hear a thing above the HUBBUB of children shouting to one another." 
"This HUBBUB gives me a headache." 
Sometimes HUBBUB is used about any kind of confused situation. 
"We lost sight of each other in the HUBBUB of the marketplace."

PITEOUS.deftext:
deserving pity, sorrowful, distressing, pathetic 
PITEOUS is an adjective from PITY. It means "deserving or arousing PITY." See _-ous_ under Suffixes. Something is PITEOUS if it is so sad and distressing that it almost breaks your heart. 
"He could not ignore their PITEOUS cries for help." 
"With a last PITEOUS glance behind him he left his home forever." 
"The ruins of the once-great mansion were truly a PITEOUS sight." 
Other forms of the word: PITY, n.

MEEK.deftext:
mild, modest, humble, tame 
A MEEK person is mild and uncomplaining. He is not likely to stand up for his rights or get angry at anyone. Usually the word suggests that this mildness is bad, and that the MEEK person lacks spirit or confidence. 
"He was a MEEK little man who jumped whenever anyone called his name." 
"She MEEKLY begged our pardon for having interrupted us." 
"A salesman should not be MEEK when talking to customers." 
_Small_ is the most common incorrect choice on the Pretest, probably because MEEK people are often pictured as being _small_ and weak.

LABYRINTH.deftext:
a maze 
In Greek mythology, the LABYRINTH was a bewilderingly complicated network of passages in which a dreaded beast, the Minotaur, was kept. LABYRINTH has come to be used about any similarly complicated structure through which it is difficult to find your way without help, a _maze._ The word is also used about a situation or a state of affairs which is entangled or hard to get through. 
"It was impossible to make your way through the LABYRINTH of plots and subplots in the novel." 
Other forms of the word: LABYRINTHINE, adj.

HEARTEN.deftext:
to give heart to, encourage, cheer 
HEARTEN comes from the word _heart._ To HEARTEN is to put _heart_ into, to give courage, hope, or enthusiasm to. 
"The soldiers were very depressed, but the general's speech HEARTENED them considerably." 
"The teacher was HEARTENED by her students' love for learning." 
"They were three runs behind, but they were HEARTENED by the thought that their best hitters were coming up." 
Many people think HEARTEN means _sadden,_ which is an opposite. These people may confuse HEARTEN with DISHEARTEN, which means to _discourage._

ACCLAIM.deftext:
to praise, applaud; to announce, proclaim 
ACCLAIM comes from a Latin word meaning to _shout_, also the source of the word _clamor._ To ACCLAIM something is to praise it, especially publicly and enthusiastically. 
"The crowd ACCLAIMED the heroes returning from the war." 
"The critics ACCLAIMED the new movie as one of the greatest ever made." 
In a different sense, ACCLAIM can mean "to declare publicly and approvingly." 
"The noblemen ACCLAIMED him their new king." 
ACCLAIM is also a noun, meaning _great praise._ 
"The play received great ACCLAIM at its first performance." 
Other forms of the word: ACCLAMATION, n.

TOIL.deftext:
labor, hard work 
TOIL is hard work, labor which wearies or exhausts a person. 
"It took years of TOIL to produce his masterpiece." 
"She always said that TOIL and trouble build one's character." 
TOIL is also used as a verb meaning to _work hard._ 
"The farmer was TOILING in the field under the hot sun." 
"He TOILED at rebuilding the house." 
Many people choose _confusion_ as the meaning of TOIL, perhaps because TOIL looks like _turmoil,_ which means _disorder, confusion._

REVERT.deftext:
to return, turn back 
See _re-_ under Prefixes. The _vert_ part of the word means _turn_ and is found in other words like _convert_ and _avert._ To REVERT is to turn back or return to an original condition, topic, idea, or the like. 
"After four years of being good he REVERTED to his former evil ways." 
"I hate to keep REVERTING to my original question, but no one has given me a satisfactory answer yet." 
In law, REVERT is used about property or rights which return to someone under certain conditions. 
"Upon his death, all his property will REVERT to the state." 
Other forms of the word: REVERSION, n.

OBLITERATE.deftext:
to erase, wipe out, destroy 
To OBLITERATE something is to cover it up or wipe it out completely, so that nothing remains or can be seen. 
"The dark clouds completely OBLITERATED the sun." 
"The incoming waves OBLITERATED all traces of the drawing he had made in the sand." 
OBLITERATE is a very strong word. It can mean to _destroy utterly._ 
"The enemy's bombs OBLITERATED the town." 
_Break_ is the most common mistake as the meaning of OBLITERATE. _Break_ is a much weaker word than OBLITERATE, though. You can _break_ something without OBLITERATING it. 
Other forms of the word: OBLITERATION, n.

ARMAMENT.deftext:
weapons, military equipment 
ARMAMENT means _weapons,_ especially those used in warfare. It is related to the word _arms,_ which can also mean weapons. 
"The warships were provided with all the latest ARMAMENT." 
It is often used in the plural for the total military strength of a country. 
"We must have better ARMAMENTS if this nation is to be strong."

LITERAL.deftext:
exact, true to fact 
LITERAL comes from the Latin word for _letter,_ also the source of the word _literature._ LITERAL means "following the words or the meaning of the original exactly." A LITERAL translation is an exact translation, one which says precisely what the original writer said in another language. The "LITERAL sense of a word" is its exact original meaning. 
"He was thrown out of the game in the LITERAL sense of the words; two players picked him up and tossed him off the field." 
The adverb LITERALLY is often used to mean _actually, truly, without exaggeration._ 
"He LITERALLY fell flat on his face the first time he tried to rollerskate."

SIMPLETON.deftext:
a fool, idiot 
A SIMPLETON is a person who is or acts simple-minded. He is silly and easily fooled and sometimes lacks the ability to get along in the world. 
"He was such a SIMPLETON that we didn't want to take advantage of him." 
"We felt like SIMPLETONS after he showed how he had fooled us."

TARRY.deftext:
to delay, lag, be slow; to remain, stay 
TARRY has two meanings. The first meaning of TARRY is to _delay_ or _hang back,_ to _be slow_ in coming or going, to _dawdle._ 
"He TARRIES so long getting dressed that he's always late for school." 
"Her mother called up to her, 'Don't TARRY any longer; we're leaving immediately.' 
" The other meaning of TARRY is to _stay_ or _remain._ 
"We TARRIED at the seashore for a few more days." 
"Please TARRY awhile; we enjoy hearing about your travels." 
_Rush_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer on the Pretest, perhaps because TARRY sounds like _hurry._

questions.prompt: Do people usually dislike hearing DEROGATORY remarks about themselves?
Is it possible to RECOUP your health after an illness?
Does it require INGENUITY to add two and two?
Does polishing metal give it a SHEEN?
Would a movie star who wanted to avoid photographers travel INCOGNITO?
Do loudspeakers STIFLE the sound of a record?
Would a book about the Civil War present a PANORAMA of American history?
If you know very little French, will you FLOUNDER when you try to speak it?
Would a small tax increase NEGATE a large pay raise?
Is a million dollars a PALTRY sum of money?
Are INCOHERENT speeches easy to listen to?
Would a VERBATIM report be very accurate?
Do adults usually disapprove of INSOLENT children?
These courses are DEROGATORY; everyone must take them.
The gambler tried to RECOUP his losses by betting more heavily.
We were amazed by the INGENUITY of his new invention.
The polished oak table had a golden SHEEN.
We were told to travel to the meeting INCOGNITO, so we wore disguises and we didn't use our real names.
The coach STIFLED them to try even harder during the second half.
We admired the bird's fancy PLUMAGE.
They drove to the city in the PANORAMA.
That one destructive storm completely NEGATED our months of work on the barn.
I can't be bothered with such PALTRY tasks; give me something important to do.
The man was so frightened that he trembled and his speech was INCOHERENT.
She repeated the boss's orders VERBATIM.
The workers TROD through the kitchen in their muddy boots.
The young man was so INSOLENT we told him to leave the room.

DEROGATORY.deftext:
degrading, detracting, disparaging 
Something that is DEROGATORY tends to take away from the value or reputation of someone or something. The word is usually used about expressions or remarks. 
"The other children made DEROGATORY comments about the odd way he walked." 
"Many police officers think that the word 'cop' is DEROGATORY, and they get angry whenever they hear it." 
"You shouldn't make DEROGATORY statements about other people's beliefs."

RECOUP.deftext:
to recover, regain, get back, make up for 
To RECOUP means to _get back_ or _make good on_ something that has been lost. See _re-_ under Prefixes. Often the word suggests getting back not the same thing that has been lost but its equivalent. 
"By shrewd investing he managed to RECOUP the fortune he had lost." 
"The family never RECOUPED the losses they suffered in the fire."

INGENUITY.deftext:
cleverness, skillfulness, originality 
INGENUITY is cleverness in coming up with ideas or inventions. It is related to the words _genius_ and _ingenious._ 
"He was a man of great INGENUITY. He could figure his way out of any difficulty." 
"Thanks to her INGENUITY we found a way to buy a new car and save money at the same time." 
INGENUITY is also used about the idea or invention itself. 
"The INGENUITY of the device astounded everyone." 
"Despite the INGENUITY of his theory, we tend to think he is wrong." 
On the Pretest, many people select _knowledge_ as the synonym of INGENUITY. You can know a great deal, however, and lack the INGENUITY to make use of your _knowledge._

SHEEN.deftext:
brightness, shine, gloss, luster 
SHEEN is gleaming brightness or luster, like that of well-polished wood. 
"The SHEEN of the bird's wings glistened in the sun." 
"Her silk dress had a beautiful SHEEN to it."

INCOGNITO.deftext:
disguised, with one's identity concealed 
INCOGNITO comes originally from a Latin word meaning _unknown._ Someone who is INCOGNITO wants to keep his or her true identity unknown. The word is often used about famous people who travel under an assumed name or in disguise so that they won't be bothered. 
"The movie star came to the theater INCOGNITO, but his fans recognized him anyway." 
"The prince went INCOGNITO among the soldiers, trying to discover how they felt about the coming battle."

STIFLE.deftext:
to suffocate, smother; to suppress, keep back 
To STIFLE someone is to kill him by not letting him breathe, to _suffocate_ him. 
"The murderer STIFLED his victim with a pillow." 
STIFLE is also used in a general sense, meaning to _cut off_ or _hold back._ 
"She managed to STIFLE a sneeze." 
"They accused the king of trying to STIFLE all political parties." 
"Bill thought his job was STIFLING him; he longed for more excitement and challenge."

PLUMAGE.deftext:
feathers 
A PLUME is a single feather. 
"She stuck a PLUME in her hat." The suffix _-age_ can mean a _group_ or _collection._ For example, baggage is a group of bags or suitcases. PLUMAGE, therefore, is a group of feathers. It is the feathers of a bird, taken all together. 
"The peacock has very colorful PLUMAGE."

PANORAMA.deftext:
a wide view, a continually changing scene 
PANORAMA was originally the name of a kind of picture that was shown a part at a time by being unrolled in front of the viewer. In this way it could give a complete view of a landscape or a scene. PANORAMA has come to be used about any wide or constantly changing view. 
"From the top of the building you can see a PANORAMA of the city." 
"His book looks over the PANORAMA of recent American history." 
"The movie is a real PANORAMA of modern life." 
Other forms of the word: PANORAMIC, adj.

FLOUNDER.deftext:
to move clumsily, muddle, wallow 
To FLOUNDER is to move clumsily, particularly to fling your arms and legs this way and that in trying to regain your balance or to escape from something. 
"The poor swimmers FLOUNDERED in the deep water, trying to stay afloat." 
"They FLOUNDERED through the snowdrifts, falling down often." 
FLOUNDER can also be used in a broader sense. 
"He FLOUNDERED through the speech, constantly forgetting what he was supposed to say next." 
"She FLOUNDERED about in the kitchen, wishing she knew something about cooking."

NEGATE.deftext:
to rule out, nullify, neutralize 
NEGATE is related to the word _negative._ Both come from a Latin word meaning to _say no._ To NEGATE something is to cause it to have no effect or value. Often the word suggests two things canceling each other out because of their opposite effects. 
"His grand slam homer NEGATED the four runs the other team had scored in the previous inning." 
"The principal's opposition NEGATES the possibility of a school outing." 
"All our work was NEGATED when money ran out and the project ended." 
"He found it difficult to NEGATE the bad impression he had already made on people." 
Other forms of the word: NEGATION, n.

PALTRY.deftext:
petty, insignificant, worthless, trivial 
Something that is PALTRY is of very little importance or value. PALTRY is a strong word, and would be used of people or things that are hardly worth noticing. 
"Ten cents is a PALTRY sum of money to have such an argument about." 
"I wouldn't bother punishing him for such a PALTRY offense." 
"Paul's always late, and he always has some PALTRY excuse."

INCOHERENT.deftext:
disorganized, disjointed, unintelligible 
The _her_ part of INCOHERENT means to stick; this root is also found in the word _adhere._ Something that is COHERENT sticks together. See _co-_ under Prefixes. The word is usually used about people or arguments that make sense, that are logical and organized. 
"He gave a COHERENT summary of everything that happened that day." 
Someone or something that is INCOHERENT is disorganized, illogical, lacks order or sense. See _in-2_ under Prefixes. 
"His explanation of how the complicated machine works was totally INCOHERENT; no one could understand him." 
"She was so angry she became INCOHERENT and just started shouting and banging the table." 
Other forms of the word: INCOHERENCE, n.

VERBATIM.deftext:
word for word 
VERBATIM comes from the Latin word that means _word,_ also the source of English words like _verb_ and _verbal._ VERBATIM means "in exactly the same words." 
"She has an amazing memory. She can recite an entire poem VERBATIM after looking at it only once." 
"The secretary took down the entire speech VERBATIM and typed it out later." 
VERBATIM is also used as an adjective. 
"He gave a VERBATIM report of what the general had said."

TREAD.deftext:
to walk, step; to stamp, crush 
To TREAD is to _walk_ or _step._ 
"A slogan during the American Revolution was 'Don't TREAD on me.' " 
"They TROD through the thick carpet of leaves on the lawn." 
"Don't TREAD on that ice. It's very thin." 
TREAD often suggests pressure and weight, and gives the idea of crushing or beating down. 
"The thoughtless children TROD all over the beautiful flowers." 
Usage: TREAD is often followed by on. The past tense of TREAD is TROD.

INSOLENT.deftext:
rude, offensive, disrespectful, insulting 
Someone who is INSOLENT lacks proper respect for people. An INSOLENT person is rude and insulting, especially to a person who is in a higher position. 
"The INSOLENT private refused to salute the general." 
"Some INSOLENT students laughed during the principal's speech." 
INSOLENT is also used about the way such a person acts, or what he says. 
"When asked why he was late, he gave an INSOLENT reply." 
Other forms of the word: INSOLENCE, n.

questions.prompt: Is Santa Claus supposed to be JOVIAL?
Is the play Hamlet an ANECDOTE?
Could an atom bomb ANNIHILATE a city?
Is a CIRCUITOUS route the fastest one?
Can you go to jail for DEFRAUDING someone?
Is a DISCORD pleasant to hear?
Is it easy to sleep in a BEDLAM?
It is usual for many people to belong to a CASTE?
When you DEVISE something, do you split it in half?
Would a hidden passage be CONSPICUOUS?
Does a person walking toward you appear to DWINDLE in size?
Would the GIST of a story be added to the end of it?
This problem is too JOVIAL for us to bother about.
Our uncle told us an ANECDOTE about the time he had lunch with a movie star.
His punch didn't hurt, it just ANNIHILATED me a little.
They are two respectable citizens who enjoy playing PANDEMONIUM.
His arguments were CIRCUITOUS, and no one could quite understand where they were all leading.
Her DISSIPATION in this project has helped us immensely.
He DEFRAUDED them to everyone as the criminals they really were.
We smelled the wonderful HUE of the rose.
There was considerable DISCORD as a result of the school board's decision to make the school year longer.
BEDLAM broke out in the classroom.
It was impossible for her to move into a higher CASTE.
The scientist DEVISED a better method for treating cancer.
Try not to be too CONSPICUOUS in the store. I don't want anyone to know we're there.
She's been out of work for over a year and her savings have DWINDLED considerably.
The GIST of his argument is that we did it before, so we can do it again.

JOVIAL.deftext:
jolly, merry, good-humored 
_Jove_ is another name for the ancient Roman god _Jupiter,_ after whom the planet Jupiter is named. In astrology, Jupiter is supposed to be the source of joy and happiness. Someone who is JOVIAL is influenced by Jupiter, is full of good humor and fun. See _-al_ under Suffixes. 
"He is a JOVIAL old man, always laughing and making jokes." 
"She pretended to be JOVIAL when she found out she had failed the test, but we could tell she was disappointed and unhappy." 
During the Pretest, many people think JOVIAL means _friendly._ A person could be _friendly,_ however, without being merry and jolly. 
Other forms of the word: JOVIALITY, n.

ANECDOTE.deftext:
a brief tale, story 
An ANECDOTE is a short, true story, usually amusing, about a person or an event. An ANECDOTE is told to give a picture of a famous person's character, to illustrate some truth, or just to entertain. 
"The musician told us several humorous ANECDOTES about famous singers for whom he had played." 
"The first chapter in the book is just a series of ANECDOTES of Harry Truman's childhood." 
"The speaker began by telling us a couple of ANECDOTES about his travels in India."

ANNIHILATE.deftext:
to destroy completely, demolish 
See _ad-_ under Prefixes and _-ate1_ under Suffixes. The _nihil_ part of ANNIHILATE is the Latin word for _nothing._ To ANNIHILATE something is to turn it into nothing, to destroy it so completely that nothing remains. 
"The general said he didn't want just to defeat the enemy, he wanted to ANNIHILATE them." 
"The city was ANNIHILATED by the atomic explosion." 
"They ANNIHILATED the other football team; the score was 69-6!" 
Other forms of the word: ANNIHILATION, n.

PANDEMONIUM.deftext:
uproar, wild disorder, tumult, chaos 
PANDEMONIUM was made up from two Greek words meaning "all the demons." The word was first used by John Milton in his poem _Paradise Lost_ as the name of the capital of Hell. Since then it has come to be used about any scene of wild noise and disorder. 
"PANDEMONIUM broke out in the stands when we won the championship." 
"There was PANDEMONIUM in the classroom whenever the teacher left." 
"Stay away from that part of town. It's utter PANDEMONIUM on Saturday nights."

CIRCUITOUS.deftext:
roundabout, indirect 
CIRCUITOUS is an adjective from the word CIRCUIT. See _-ous_ under Suffixes. Both words are related to the word _circle._ The basic meaning of CIRCUIT is "a journey or route around something." 
"We made a CIRCUIT around the flooded area." 
CIRCUITOUS is used about routes, trips, and the like and means "taking the long way round," _roundabout._ 
"We got lost and ended up taking a somewhat CIRCUITOUS route, but we still managed to get there on time." 
"They took a CIRCUITOUS journey through the mountains; they were more interested in seeing the scenery than in going quickly." 
The word can also be used in a general sense to mean _indirect, not straightforward._ 
"We had difficulty following his CIRCUITOUS reasoning, but at last he began to make sense." 
Other forms of the word: CIRCUIT, n.

DISSIPATE.deftext:
to scatter, disperse, waste 
DISSIPATE means to _scatter_ or _dissolve._ 
"The hot sun DISSIPATED the early morning fog." 
"He never got anything done. His time just seemed to DISSIPATE." 
Very often DISSIPATE has the sense of scattering foolishly, of _wasting._ 
"Because of his gambling, William managed to DISSIPATE his inheritance within a year." 
The noun DISSIPATION means a _wasting_ or _scattering_; it is usually used in descriptions of wasted lives. 
"We hadn't seen him in several years. He was terribly changed by the life of DISSIPATION he had led." 
Other forms of the word: DISSIPATION, n.

DEFRAUD.deftext:
to cheat, trick, get by fraud 
A FRAUD is an act of trickery. 
"He posed as a jewelry expert and got the ring from her by FRAUD." 
To DEFRAUD someone is to take something away from him by FRAUD, to _cheat_ him. See _de-_ under Prefixes. "One of the partners DEFRAUDED the others of their share of the profits." 
"The young man was DEFRAUDED of his inheritance by the dishonest lawyers." 
"The crook DEFRAUDED several people of their life's savings."

HUE.deftext:
color, tint, shade 
HUE means just about the same thing as color. 
"Her dress included all the HUES of the rainbow." 
"For the ceiling, he chose a paint of a slightly lighter HUE." 
"The sky turned a strange HUE, and we all knew there was bad weather coming." 
_Smell_ and _sight_ are the most commonly chosen incorrect answers. People who pick these words probably know that HUE has something to do with the senses, but aren't exactly sure what. 
Usage: HUE is usually used in poetic or literary kinds of writing.

DISCORD.deftext:
conflict, strife, disagreement, lack of harmony 
In music, a _chord_ is a combination of two or more tones sounded together. DISCORD is related to _chord_. A DISCORD in music is a chord which has a harsh or unpleasant sound. See _dis-_ under Prefixes. DISCORD is also used generally about situations where people or things are not in harmony with one another. 
"There was a great deal of DISCORD at the meeting; no one could agree about anything." 
"Jill couldn't stand the DISCORD among the members of her family." 
"The long years of DISCORD between the two countries finally resulted in war." 
Other forms of the word: DISCORDANT, adj.

BEDLAM.deftext:
a madhouse, insane asylum; confused noise 
BEDLAM was the name of an insane asylum in London; from this the word came to mean any madhouse or insane asylum. Then, because a madhouse was supposed to be a place full of noise and screaming, BEDLAM took on the meaning of"a scene of noise, uproar, and confusion." 
"Everyone in the room began to yell at once; the place turned into a BEDLAM." 
"The playground was a BEDLAM of little children shouting and running every which way." 
"It was BEDLAM around here until our parents returned."

CASTE.deftext:
a social class 
In India, CASTES are the various social classes that people are born into. Which CASTE you belong to can limit the occupations you can have and the people you can deal with. Thus a CASTE is a separate and exclusive class of society. 
"He belonged to the highest CASTE, so he felt such a job was beneath him." 
"The people who knew how to cure illnesses formed a separate CASTE within their society." 
"If you were born into the lowest CASTE, you could not expect to become very successful."

DEVISE.deftext:
to invent, formulate, plan, contrive 
To DEVISE something is to make it up or _invent it,_ usually through a new arrangement of ideas or parts that already exist. 
"He DEVISED a new method for filing the cards." 
"They DEVISED a scheme to cheat the insurance company." 
"Jim DEVISED a good radio out of some spare parts on his workbench." 
_Change_ and _fix_ are common choices as the correct meaning of DEVISE. This may be due to confusing DEVISE with revise. To DEVISE something is to invent it. To _revise_ something is to change it with the idea of making it better. 
"After he DEVISED the system he revised it several times in order to improve it."

CONSPICUOUS.deftext:
obvious, noticeable, striking 
CONSPICUOUS comes from a Latin word meaning to see, also the source of other English words like _spy__ and _spectacles._ Something that is CONSPICUOUS is very easy to see. It stands out from everything around it. 
"Put the _No Smoking_ sign in a CONSPICUOUS place so that everyone will notice it." 
"She was very CONSPICUOUS in her huge orange hat." 
In a slightly different sense, CONSPICUOUS means "attracting attention," because something is out of the ordinary in some way. 
"He received a medal for his CONSPICUOUS bravery during the battle." 
"The team's most CONSPICUOUS problem is its complete inability to score goals."

DWINDLE.deftext:
to shrink, decrease, decline 
To DWINDLE is to become smaller in size, number, or importance. 
"The number of students applying to that college has been steadily DWINDLING for several years, until now almost no one wants to go there." 
"The importance of railroads started to DWINDLE with the development of a national highway system." 
"The snowman DWINDLED as the sun shone on it, until finally it all melted away." 
_Waste time_ is the most commonly wrong answer on the Pretest, probably because of confusion with the word _dawdle._

GIST.deftext:
the main part, main idea, essence, general sense 
GIST is a legal term, meaning "the grounds for a legal action"—that is, the basic reason or point of a case. In general use GIST has the same idea: it is the main point, the central idea of something. 
"Don't repeat the whole speech to me. I just want the GIST of what he said." 
"There was a lot more to it, but the GIST of his decision is that you can't come."

questions.prompt: In the middle of the TUMULT.
Would a train be IMPEDED by a truck on the tracks?
Are some bears DORMANT during the winter?
Does your supply of money DIMINISH when you spend some?
Could someone go on a JAUNT to the zoo?
Would a riot be considered a TUMULT?
Would a well-CLAD person have holes in his socks?
Would someone who sells furniture be called a MERCHANT?
Do people enjoy being in ANGUISH?
Are people generally SOMBER at a wedding?
Does the teacher have JURISDICTION in the classroom?
Can a NARRATIVE be very short?
Does a king rule a REALM?
If there are no unexpected IMPEDIMENTS, we should be finished on time.
My talent for writing was DORMANT for many years until a friend in publishing persuaded me to write a book.
The wrecking crew completely DIMINISHED the building in a few hours.
Magellan's JAUNT around the world lasted several years.
They were so ashamed of themselves that they just stood there in TUMULTUOUS silence.
The knight was CLAD in shining armor.
Some commercial banks discourage small savings accounts; they prefer to deal with large MERCANTILE outfits.
I will never forget the ANGUISHED look on his face when his dog died.
She thought the dirty language in the movie was DEPLORABLE.
These problems are EFFERVESCENT; I don't think we'll ever solve them.
The stained glass window was beautifully ORNATE. It would take you hours to notice all the details.
The hotel was filled with SOMBER, poorly lit passageways that made us feel a little frightened.
After many days of debate the jury finally reached a JURISDICTION.
They listened to the exciting NARRATIVE of his adventures.
The teacher said that my getting an A in English was not within the REALM of possibility.

IMPEDIMENT.deftext:
an obstacle, obstruction, hindrance 
The verb IMPEDE comes from the Latin word for _foot,_ which is also the source of the English words _pedal_ and _pedestrian._ The original Latin meaning of IMPEDE was "to snare the feet." Today it means more generally "to obstruct the progress of," to _hinder._ 
"The constant floods IMPEDED their journey." An IMPEDIMENT is something which IMPEDES, an _obstacle._ 
"Lack of money was the main IMPEDIMENT to the successful completion of the project." 
"He had a speech IMPEDIMENT that kept him from talking easily." 
Other forms of the word: IMPEDE,v.

DORMANT.deftext:
inactive 
DORMANT comes originally from a Latin word meaning to _sleep,_ also the source of the word _dormitory._ DORMANT means lying asleep or as if asleep. It is used about things which are inactive now, but are capable of becoming active in the future. 
"During the winter, trees become DORMANT. In the spring they seem to come alive again and put out new leaves." 
"After years of being DORMANT the volcano suddenly erupted." 
"Her ability to paint lay DORMANT for many years. She didn't start to draw and sketch until she was past fifty."

DIMINISH.deftext:
to lessen, decrease, dwindle 
To DIMINISH is to make less, or to become less. 
"Nothing could DIMINISH my interest in history." 
"The value of our house DIMINISHED when they decided to build an expressway next to it." 
"His wealth DIMINISHED as a result of poor investments." 
"Our food supply was greatly DIMINISHED by the end of the day." 
The most common wrong answer on the Pretest is _stop._ 
To DIMINISH something is not to _stop_ it, though,only to lessen it.

JAUNT.deftext:
a short trip, excursion 
A JAUNT is a short, casual trip taken for pleasure. 
"We took a quick JAUNT to the beach." 
"They went on a JAUNT to see the city sights." 
JAUNT can also be used as a verb. 
"She liked to JAUNT through the lovely parks. "

TUMULT.deftext:
an uproar, noise, disturbance, commotion 
A TUMULT is any sort of uproar or disturbance. 
"The politician was greeted with a TUMULT of cheers." 
"There was a sudden silence in the midst of the TUMULT." 
TUMULT is often used about highly disturbed emotions. 
"Her feelings were in a TUMULT as she waited for the door to open." 
The adjective form of TUMULT is TUMULTUOUS, which means _noisy_ or _disorderly._ 
"The star received TUMULTUOUS applause when he came on stage." 
"The teacher tried to calm the TUMULTUOUS crowd of children." 
Other forms of the word: TUMULTUOUS, adj.

CLAD.deftext:
dressed, clothed 
CLAD is an old form of the past tense of the verb to _clothe._ When the word is used in this way, it usually has an old-fashioned flavor. 
"The princess was CLAD in the finest Japanese silk." 
Usually CLAD is an adjective, used with another word as part of a phrase. 
"Poorly CLAD beggars roamed the streets of the town." 
An IRONCLAD ship is covered with iron plates, usually as armor. From this IRONCLAD has come to be used about anything that is impossible to break. 
"We had an IRONCLAD agreement to help each other."

MERCANTILE.deftext:
related to trade, commercial 
A MERCHANT is someone who buys and sells a product for profit. MERCANTILE is an adjective from MERCHANT and means "of or related to MERCHANTS or trading." 
"It was a MERCANTILE city, famous for its many large businesses." 
"The MERCANTILE interests in the legislature supported all bills that would help increase trade." 
Other forms of the word: MERCHANT, n.

ANGUISH.deftext:
suffering, sorrow, distress, woe, agony 
ANGUISH is extreme suffering. The suffering can be either mental or physical. 
"Her son's death in an automobile accident caused her great ANGUISH." 
"Nothing we could do could relieve her ANGUISH when her house burned down." 
"The soldier was in ANGUISH until the doctor came to treat his wound." 
ANGUISH is also a verb. 
"Mary ANGUISHED over the loss of her home and belongings in the fire." 
ANGUISHED is the adjective from ANGUISH. 
"Her ANGUISHED cries told us that something was terribly wrong." 
_Rage_ is the incorrect answer that is most often chosen. This is probably due to a confusion between ANGUISH and _anger._ Other forms of the word: ANGUISHED, adj.

DEPLORABLE.deftext:
wretched, bad, causing grief or regret 
To DEPLORE something is to feel great regret, disapproval, or sorrow about it. 
"He DEPLORED the conditions in which the miners had to work." 
DEPLORABLE is the adjective from DEPLORE. See _-able_ under Suffixes. Something which is DEPLORABLE is _wretched,_ bad enough to cause strong disapproval. 
"When we arrived at our new apartment we found that the people living there before us had left it in a DEPLORABLE condition." 
"Wendy's grandmother told her that her manners were DEPLORABLE." 
Sometimes the word is used about something that causes sorrow rather than disapproval. 
"The people wept bitterly upon hearing of the DEPLORABLE death of their president." 
"They had never before witnessed such a DEPLORABLE accident." Other forms of the word: DEPLORE, v.

EFFERVESCENT.deftext:
bubbling, exuberant, lively 
The _ferv_ part of EFFERVESCENT comes from a Latin word meaning to _boil,_ also the source of the word _fervent._ To EFFERVESCE is to give off bubbles of gas the way a carbonated soft drink or champagne does. EFFERVESCENT is the adjective from EFFERVESCE. The word is usually used in a general sense about people who are so lively and excitable that they seem to bubbleover with enthusiasm, joy, or ideas. 
"Her EFFERVESCENT enthusiasm made everyone else try twice as hard." 
"His EFFERVESCENT personality would enliven any party." 
"Jane's EFFERVESCENT imagination came up with a hundred ways of solving the problem." 
Other forms of the word: EFFERVESCE, v. EFFERVESCENCE, n.

ORNATE.deftext:
elaborately or excessively decorated, showy 
ORNATE is related to the word _ornament._ Something which is ORNATE is highly decorated or ornamented. 
"The chair was very ORNATE, covered with scrolls and designs and patterns." 
"We stared at the ORNATE design on the ceiling of the church." 
ORNATE is often used about writing which is full of flowery language. 
"Some people like this ORNATE style of writing. I like writing to be simple and clear."

SOMBER.deftext:
gloomy, dark, dark colored, dismal 
SOMBER means _gloomy, dark,_ or _shadowy._ It is used about things and people's moods. 
"It was customary for relatives of the dead person to dress in SOMBER clothes for at least a year." 
"SOMBER clouds filled the sky." 
"She put on a SOMBER look, even though she was secretly pleased." 
"He couldn't shake off his SOMBER mood." 
Many people think SOMBER means _bored._ SOMBER, however, emphasizes gloominess and depression rather than boredom.

JURISDICTION.deftext:
authority, power, control 
JURISDICTION comes from the Latin word for _law,_ also the source of _jury._ JURISDICTION is the legal power to administer justice and decide cases. 
"Our courts have JURISDICTION over foreigners living in the United States." 
"The judge said it wasn't within his JURISDICTION to decide this question." 
The word can be used in a broader sense for any authority or power that has well-defined limits. 
"Your complaint does not come within our JURISDICTION. Try another department." 
The most popular wrong answer is _decision._ People who choose this probably know that JURISDICTION has something to do with the law, but don't know exactly what. JURISDICTION is the authority to make a legal decision, not the decision itself.

NARRATIVE.deftext:
a story, tale To NARRATE a story is to tell it. 
"He NARRATED a story about a boy and his dog living on a farm." 
A NARRATIVE is a story, the telling of a series of events. 
A NARRATIVE can be either true or made up. 
"They read an exciting NARRATIVE about pirates and buried treasure." 
"We listened to the NARRATIVE of the first spaceflight." 
Other forms of the word: NARRATE, v. NARRATOR, n.

REALM.deftext:
a kingdom, territory, region 
REALM is a fancy or poetical word for _kingdom._ 
"The king searched throughout his REALM for one honest man." 
The word is also used in a general sense for _region, territory, or range._ 
"He lived entirely within the REALM of his own imagination." 
If something is "within the REALM of possibility," it is possible, it can happen. 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer is tale, possibly because REALM is connected in people's minds with stories and legends rather than with everyday speech.

questions.prompt: To ASSERT that it is true.
Is a DICTATORIAL boss fun to work for?
Do most people RELISH the idea of going hungry?
Would you DON your shoes when you're going to bed?
Does a person who is unemployed have a good LIVELIHOOD?
Could a person ASSERT that something is true when it really isn't?
Would a witch INVOKE evil spirits?
Does an automobile have any UTILITY?
Can a desk drawer be PARTITIONED?
Can a person GROPE for words?
Would you REPRIMAND someone for being a hero?
Do PRESUMPTUOUS people think they know a lot?
Do runners ENDEAVOR to break records?
The DICTATORIAL secretary was extremely fast at taking shorthand.
He told the story of his opponent's arrest with obvious RELISH.
Jack DONNED his new suit for his first day on the job.
He lost his LIVELIHOOD when the factory closed down.
The patriot openly ASSERTED his love for his country.
They INVOKED Bill's license because of his many speeding tickets.
We'll never UTILIZE all this equipment. You'll have to take some back.
They PARTITIONED us to come with them.
Joe GROPED in the closet for the old pair of shoes.
He said the belief that airlines were unsafe was a FALLACY.
You will only receive a REPRIMAND this time; next time you will be put in jail.
It was PRESUMPTUOUS of you to think you could take the car without asking me first.
The kitten HURTLED across the room when it saw its supper being prepared.
The bird curved its TALONS around the thin branch.
The ENDEAVOR to put a man on the moon was finally successful.

DICTATORIAL.deftext:
like a DICTATOR, overbearing, oppressive 
A DICTATOR is a person who rules a country by himself, usually in a cruel way. DICTATORIAL is the adjective from DICTATOR and means "like a DICTATOR." See _-al_ under Suffixes. The word suggests a person who is so used to power that he expects everyone to obey him. 
"Her father's DICTATORIAL attitude bothered Cathy. He would punish her if she didn't obey him immediately." 
"The teacher believes you don't have to be DICTATORIAL to make students learn. Being pleasant and understanding often works better." 
Other forms of the word: DICTATOR, n.

RELISH.deftext:
to enjoy, take delight in 
To RELISH something is to enjoy it greatly, to take delight in it. 
"They RELISH singing. They sing every chance they get." 
"I RELISH the idea of going to camp this summer." 
"I don't RELISH the thought of having to sweep the floor." 
RELISH is also a noun, meaning enjoyment. 
"She led the parade with great RELISH." 
"I have little RELISH for getting up so early."

DON.deftext:
to put on, dress in 
DON is used about clothing, and means to _put on._ 
"The king DONNED his finest robes when he went to meet them." 
"She DONNED a brand new hat for Easter." 
"Jane DONNED her favorite gown to go to the dance." 
Most people who get this word wrong on the Pretest choose _take off_ as its meaning. This is the exact opposite of DON. A similar-sounding word, _doff,_ means to _take off,_ and this may cause some of the confusion. "He DONNED his coat when he went outside, then _doffed_ it when he came back in again." Usage: DON is a rather old-fashioned word and would not usually be used in ordinary conversation.

LIVELIHOOD.deftext:
a means of support, living 
A LIVELIHOOD is a way of making a living, a means of earning money. The word can apply to the money you earn in order to live, or to the job or career from which you earn the money. 
"He gained his LIVELIHOOD by selling from door to door." 
"Raising sheep provided them with a decent LIVELIHOOD." 
Many people think LIVELIHOOD means _hobby._ A _hobby_ is something you do for fun, though, not to make a living. 
"Her parent didn't mind acting as a _hobby,_ but they disapproved of it as a LIVELIHOOD."

ASSERT.deftext:
to declare, state, affirm, maintain 
To ASSERT something is to state positively that it is true, usually without proof. 
"The defendant ASSERTED his innocence." 
"Father ASSERTED that we were too young to see that movie." 
"John ASSERTED that he was strong enough to carry the box." 
In a similar sense, ASSERT means "to put forward boldly." "If you want people to pay attention to you, you must ASSERT yourself"—that is, you must demand to be recognized or listened to. 
The most common mistake is to choose _believe_ as the meaning of ASSERT. You would usually _believe_ something that you ASSERT, but ASSERT adds the idea of declaring your belief publicly and forcefully. Other forms of the word: ASSERTION, n. ASSERTIVE, adj.

INVOKE.deftext:
to call upon, call for, appeal to, entreat, summon 
See _in-1_ under Prefixes. The _voke_ part of the word means to _call._ To _revoke_ is to call back, to _convoke_ is to call together, to _evoke_ is to call forth. INVOKE has several different uses, all of which basically mean to _call in_ or _call upon._ To INVOKE God's name is to call upon it—for example, in support of what you are saying. To INVOKE someone's mercy is to call for it, to beg for it. To INVOKE an investigation is to cause it, to call it forth. To INVOKE evil spirits is to call them forth, to summon them by magic. 
Other forms of the word: INVOCATION, n.

UTILITY.deftext:
usefulness 
UTILITY is the quality of being useful, the ability to be of use. 
"This invention might not have much UTILITY right away, but in a few years it will be very useful." 
"The teachers had an argument over the UTILITY of teaching arithmetic this way." 
A "public UTILITY" is a company that supplies an essential public service like water or electricity. 
To UTILIZE something is to make use of it. 
"Bill UTILIZED many old pieces of lumber in building the barn." 
"She has so many talents that it is difficult for her to UTILIZE them all." 
Other forms of the word: UTILIZE, v.

PARTITION.deftext:
to divide, split, separate into parts 
You can see the word _part_ in PARTITION. PARTITION means "to split or separate into parts." The word can be used with almost anything that can be made into smaller spaces. 
"After World War II, Germany was PARTITIONED into East Germany and West Germany." 
"They PARTITIONED the living room to allow for a dining area." 
"The box is PARTITIONED to hold different sizes of bottles." 
A PARTITION is something that divides or separates. 
"They used movable PARTITIONS to create separate offices in the large open space."

GROPE.deftext:
to feel about blindly, feel one's way, search blindly or uncertainly 
To GROPE for something is to feel about for it as if you were blind and could only use your hands. 
"He GROPED for the flashlight in the dark." 
"She GROPED for the ball that had rolled beneath the couch." 
"They GROPED their way through the dark tunnel." 
GROPE is also used in a more general sense for any kind of uncertain or hesitant search. 
"He GROPED for an answer to the difficult math problem." 
"She GROPED for the proper words to say how thankful she was."

FALLACY.deftext:
a false or mistaken idea; false reasoning 
In logic, a FALLACY is an incorrect line of reasoning which leads to a mistaken conclusion. For example, the following is a FALLACY: 
"If a man is shot through the head, he will die. Smith died; therefore he was shot through the head." 
Being shot through the head is obviously not the only way a man can die. A particular error in logic has been made which makes the conclusion false. These errors are called, in general, FALLACIES. 
In everyday use, a FALLACY is an idea which is false or mistaken, usually because of faulty reasoning. 
"The theory that boys are smarter than girls has repeatedly been shown to be a FALLACY." 
Other forms of the word: FALLACIOUS, adj.

REPRIMAND.deftext:
to scold, rebuke, censure, reprove 
To REPRIMAND someone is to scold him severely for having done something wrong. 
"Her parents REPRIMANDED her for staying out so late without permission." 
REPRIMAND usually has the sense of an official, formal censure. 
"The soldier was officially REPRIMANDED for not following orders." 
REPRIMAND is also a noun. 
"The president of the company sent him a letter of REPRIMAND for missing work." 
_Arrest_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer. REPRIMANDING a person falls far short of _arresting_ him and putting him in jail, however.

PRESUMPTUOUS.deftext:
overconfident, arrogant, audacious 
To PRESUME to do something is to dare to do it, to take the liberty of doing it. 
"The bold soldier PRESUMED to call the general by his first name." Someone who is PRESUMPTUOUS PRESUMES too much. He is too bold and confident and assumes he has the right to do things when he really hasn't. See _-ous_ under Suffixes. 
"It was PRESUMPTUOUS of him to think that I would go along with whatever he decided." 
"The PRESUMPTUOUS assistant decided he knew what to do and wouldn't wait for the boss's orders." 
"He was never PRESUMPTUOUS, but always waited patiently for the permission of his superiors to do anything." 
The most commonly chosen incorrect answer is _impolite._ PRESUMPTUOUS people might often be _impolite,_ but PRESUMPTUOUS has a much more specific meaning than that. Other forms of the word: PRESUME, v. PRESUMPTION, n.

HURTLE.deftext:
to rush violently, move rapidly; to drive, fling 
To HURTLE is to move rapidly and violently. The word usually emphasizes speed, noise, and violence. 
"Tons of snow HURTLED down the mountainside during the avalanche." 
"The rocket HURTLED through the air at five times the speed of sound." 
To HURTLE something is to drive it forward rapidly or violently. 
"The new train HURTLED its passengers across the country in record time."

TALON.deftext:
a claw 
A TALON is a _claw,_ especially the claw of a bird of prey like a hawk. 
"The eagle swooped down and seized the rabbit in its TALONS." 
"The bird curved its TALONS around its perch."

ENDEAVCR.deftext:
to try, make an effort, attempt, strive 
ENDEAVOR means to _try._ The word usually adds to _try_ a sense of determined effort or struggle. 
"No matter how much they ENDEAVORED, they couldn't finish in time." 
"They ENDEAVORED to clean up the house before their mother returned." 
ENDEAVOR when used as a noun emphasizes even more strongly this idea of difficulty and determination. 
"They made a serious ENDEAVOR to solve these important problems." 
"The ENDEAVOR was worthwhile, even if it did not succeed."
